course.subject: MATH
course.name: Calculus IA
course.description: This is an introductory course in one-variable calculus, the first in the Calculus I and II sequence, designed for students that have not taken HKDSE Mathematics Extended Module M1 or M2. Topics include functions and their limits, continuity, derivatives and rules of differentiation, applications of derivatives, and basic integral calculus.
course.exclusions: Level 3 or above in HKDSE Mathematics Extended Module M1 or M2; MATH 1003, MATH 1013, MATH 1014, MATH 1020, MATH 1023, MATH 1024

reviews.author: Lima
reviews.comment_content: This is an introductory course in one-variable calculus.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I only attended the first two classes, so I don't know.
But I recommend self-study as it is more time-efficient.
reviews.comment_grading:
The mean/full score:
midterm: 4X/100

It's absolute grading with grade adjustment, which may depend on the mean(?
I got an A+ with a total of around 9X(sry I forgot), while the mean is around 5X, so I honestly cannot judge whether the grading is good or not.
reviews.comment_workload: Quite light. You just need to complete the webwork assignments before the deadline, which is quite easy. Each assignment takes approximately 2 hours or less to complete.

reviews.author: asae
reviews.title: Short Review Summary
reviews.comment_content:
Clarity of Content:

The course content is presented in a clear and concise manner.
Concepts are explained with sufficient detail, aiding in understanding for students of varying mathematical backgrounds.
Visual aids, such as diagrams and graphs, enhance clarity.
Depth of Coverage:

The courses cover a broad range of calculus topics, ensuring a comprehensive understanding of fundamental concepts.
The progression from Calculus I to Calculus II is well-structured, allowing for a smooth transition between the two courses.
Integration of real-world applications helps students see the practical relevance of the materia
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching Methods:

The instructor's teaching methods are effective in engaging students.
Interactive sessions, problem-solving exercises, and discussions contribute to a dynamic learning environment.
Regular assessments and feedback mechanisms are beneficial for tracking progress.

Support and Accessibility:

The instructor is approachable and responsive to students' questions and concerns.
Additional support, such as office hours or tutoring services, is available for students who may need extra assistance.

Support and Accessibility:

The instructor is approachable and responsive to students' questions and concerns.
Additional support, such as office hours or tutoring services, is available for students who may need extra assistance.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assessment and Evaluation:

Assessments are fair and reflective of the course objectives.
Grading criteria are transparent, helping students understand how their performance aligns with learning goals.
Constructive feedback on assessments aids in continuous improvement.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not that bad.

reviews.author: Ri
reviews.comment_content: This course based on the description is supposed to be an introductory course to calculus and help you catch up with people who have taken M1 or M2 in high school. This is only a supposed as the actual course is nothing but hell. As they are attempting to teach 3 years of high school calculus in around 2 months. As someone who isn't even good at normal math, this course was probably the closest thing I'll experience to hell.
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructor is great, he's really kind and is open to questions after class if you have them. He does his best to try and teach and even does webworks at times, but he only tends to do the easier ones leaving the difficult ones to the students usually. The TA's are also ok and try to teach to the best of their abilities, but be warned that most of the time you'll have to self study.
reviews.comment_workload: If your maths is good and you have logical thinking most of the time you'll be fine with the exercises given and at least pass. If your maths isn't good, self-studying is the only way to catch up and you'll have to do a lot of it. Organic Chemistry Tutor and Khan Academy will be your best friends

reviews.author: Ethand0fined
reviews.title: An "opportunity" of self-learning
reviews.comment_content:
Topics (not exactly in order):
Absolute Number - (inequality included)
Trigonometric function -(new stuff: cotan, sec, csc + few formula, try hard to remember them although they will be provided in the last pages of the exam paper, it will be very helpful)
Inverse function
Inequality
Limits
Differentiation
Integration (including left/right Riemann sum)

All of them are basic. Concepts are not hard, it is good to learn more (at least understand the proof, how they work, and play with the formulas)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Books are not necessary, and online materials should be sufficient( + they are free).

Attending lectures and tutorials are optional. You may opt for self-learning, e.g.(YouTube channels like :
3blue1brown for concepts,
blackpenredpen for practices)

Lecture:
Skip this, you will get the video anyway.

Tutorial:
Examples are shown and explained, more helpful then lecture.
Also, there will be tutorial notes sent to you via email (With answers). So you can simply skip all tutorials if you can handle all the questions by yourself.
reviews.comment_grading:
According to my memory:
[WebWork: 100%] :
Infinite attempts, no need to worry. Act as one of the best ways of learning through experience.

[Midterm: 86/100]

[Final: 99/100] :
The exam is easier than before ( at least they said it themselves), the biggest difficulty would be trying to understand the questions.
you may look for past papers (there are websites made for this, search hkust pastpaper)

[Grade: A+] :
Definitely needs hard work, you should try different types of questions cause you will never know which type of question they are planning. I think the exam focused on the concepts, there will not be complicated questions that require lots of steps.

No calculator allowed.

background: Haven't taken M1/M2, 5* in Math
reviews.comment_workload: Workload: WebWork only, You can try to finish all of them before class as preparation so that you will get a better understanding of what is going on.

reviews.author: Edwin Lai
reviews.title: Don't be scared by mathematics, it is something you CAN deal with.
reviews.comment_content:
Well, calculus 1A
Its for those who haven't taken HKDSE M1 or M2
So it only teaches the basics of calculus including :

1. limits
2. derivatives
3. integrals

You can check the details of the course yourself so I don't list all of them here. ( Yeah it is not only 3 items :( )
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching... I would recommend attending tutorial class rather than lectures.

Tutorial class teaches WeBWorK problems so you at least get that 10%. I also got inspired by how he (Daniel Cheng) break down a question in order to solve it.

I found lectures have no use for me tho, it teaches much slower than I teach myself by solving homework problems. You SHOULD attend lectures to see if you like how it teaches.

Don't buy the book unless you really need to, it is not worth it if you only need math in the first semester. (Purchase it if you look forward to learn math in future semester)
Instead, check out the course outline and search for the explanations online (Youtube, webpage, etc.)
reviews.comment_grading:
Percentages :

WeBWorK ( Online Homework )  -  10%
Midterm Exam  -  35%
Final Exam  -  55%
_______________________

For the examinations, although I only got a 3 in HKDSE math, I would say it is ok to get a decent grade (around B, NOT A).

Take my score as reference :

WeBWorK  -  100%
Midterm  -  57%
Final  -  61%

Grade : B-

I recommend you to take a look at [ Riemann sum ] before going in the intergral part .
reviews.comment_workload:
WeBWorK part, I only got 8 homework in this semester, around 13 questions per work. If you attend the last 60% of the tutorial classes, it would be fine to complete all of them on time.

Bear in mind, you can always ask questions after lectures or tutorials, as well as those ' Only got an A person ' around you :)

reviews.author: quitUHelps
reviews.comment_content:
Mostly DSE M2 stuff

Week one:
Numbers, intervals, inequalities (Appendix A)

Week two:
Basic functions and graphs, composite functions (1.1, 1.2, 1.3)
Inequalities and absolute values

Week three:
Exponential functions,  inverse functions, logarithms (1.4, 1.5)

Week four:
Trigonometric functions and inverse trigonometric functions (1.5, Appendix D)
The limit of a function, limit laws (2.2, 2.3)
Week five: Monday  Monday (Oct 2)  (Holiday: Oct 2)
The limit of a function, limit laws (2.2, 2.3)
Continuity (2.5)

Week six:
Limits at infinity and horizontal asymptotes (2.6)

Week seven:
Tangent and velocity (2.1)
Derivatives and rates of change (2.7)
Basic derivatives (2.8, 3.1)
Product and quotient rules (3.2)
Chain rule (3.4)

Week eight:
Implicit differentiation, derivatives of inverse trigonometric functions and logarithmic functions (3.5, 3.6)

Week nine:
Rates of change problems (3.7)
Linear approximations and differentials (3.10)
Maximum and minimum values (4.1)

Week ten:
Mean Value Theorem (4.2)
Derivatives and the shape of a graph (4.3)
Curve sketching (4.5, 4.6)

Week eleven:
L'Hopital's rule (4.4)
Optimization problems (4.7)

Week twelve:
Anti-derivatives (4.9)
Area and definite integrals (5.1, 5.2)

Week thirteen:
The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus (5.3)
Substitution rule (5.5)

reviews.author: gaming!!!
reviews.comment_content:
It's calculus 1, so the content doesn't really change across years, meaning:

- You can study all the pastpapers you want
- You can study off of notes from previous years

I did 90% of my studying from a previous TA's notes:
https://sites.google.com/view/walterchan/2020-fall?authuser=0
reviews.comment_teaching:
I only attended the first lecture, then skipped everything past that and studied by myself, so I can't comment on how good the teaching us (but from the recordings that I skimmed over, you can probably skip the lectures as well).

Though, the instructor seems like a nice person.
reviews.comment_grading:
WeBWorK: 10%
Midterm Exam: 35%
Final Exam: 55%

87% --> A
I expected to get worse, but judging from how much I studied this is probably fair.
reviews.comment_workload:
Calculus is mostly just about understanding concepts --> drilling problems.

Personally, I did all of Walter Chan's notes + all pastpapers I could find, and that was enough for me. But if you need additional practice problems, Walter Chan has also linked this on his website:
https://sites.google.com/view/walterchan/2018-fall

If you distribute the study workload over a long period (aka don't cram one week before the exam, you will die), then you should be fine.

reviews.comment_content:

derivatives of inverse functions

Others are easier to manage.
reviews.comment_teaching:
C- for æ°´å±±å“¥(Tu), A- for Phyllis, Overall C+.
æ°´å±±å“¥'s spoken English has a thick mainland accent and unclear pronunciation, which can be challenging to understand. Interestingly, he pronounces 'exam' as 'example',so when putting it into a sentence, the sentence will be like ' There will be a final example next week'. During his lectures, he primarily focuses on fundamental theories that may not be directly applicable to homework and exams. However, you can find some useful things in his lecture notes and he is available to answer questions after class. Overall, I don't know why I was able to attend all his lectures.
Phyllis is often late to class, but provides helpful notes and clear explanations. Students should be prepared to preview the content before her lecture or tutorial, as she moves quickly. Some of the examples she provides may be difficult for beginners in the relevant content, and even more challenging than exams. Despite this, attending her lectures and tutorials is strongly recommended. It is sufficient to review Phyllis's notes before exams, as they are helpful and comprehensive.
There is some overlap in content between Phyllis' lectures /tutorials and æ°´å±±å“¥'s lectures, which might be a waste of time for students.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework 10%
Midterm Exam 35%
Final Exam 55%

As I mentioned in teaching, Phyllis's notes are extremely helpful in understanding the course material. The homework assignments are manageable as long as you can understand all of the notes provided by Phyllis.
mean of hw:
hw1 95.64 hw2 92.11 hw3 90.13 hw4 91.13 hw5 81.36 hw6 83.15 hw7 80.74 hw8 77.74

The midterm exam is challenging for most students, with a mean score of approximately 45. However, the final exam is better, with a mean score above 50. It's worth noting that this is a difficult course to earn a good grade in. Fortunately, I was not affected by this and received an A+ with an overall grade of 95.45(midterm 87, final 100, homework 100).

In my opinion, it's possible to achieve a better grade than the mean, let's say 70, even with some points lost due to carelessness because 85% of the questions are basic and relevant to Phyllis's notes. However, it's important to be careful and avoid making careless mistakes to maximize your score.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload for this semester is manageable with 8 homework assignments. While there may be some challenging questions, instructors are available to answer questions and students can also visit the math support center for additional assistance.

Here are some tips for reviewing:

To review Phyllis's notes, it's recommended to start by reviewing the concepts and theorems. If you find anything difficult to understand, you can refer to æ°´å±±å“¥'s notes, which provide a more fundamental explanation. Once you have a good understanding of the concepts, you can try to answer the questions and examples in Phyllis's notes on your own. After attempting the questions, it's helpful to check the answers and then summarize the methods used in the solution. This will help to reinforce your understanding of the material, rather than just memorizing the solutions.

reviews.author: 31v12
reviews.title: An Extremely Bias Review (But Still Kinda Based)
reviews.comment_content:
Wow, they actually did it, they have somehow managed to put every calculus thing in M2 in a 3-month course. Is it fun? I'll let you decide.

There are mainly 2 big topics: Preface, and Actual Calculus.

The first topic is Preface, which has a huge range of tiny stuff in it. From intervals, to composite functions, to some trigonometry stuff, and finally limits, stuff you have to understand before moving onto the actual "good" stuff. It can be overwhelming for some, but you really need to fully understand them (except trigo) before moving on, and there are couple ways to help with that, which I would talking more in the Workload section. Almost forgot, Squeeze Theorem and Intermediate Value Theorem, REMEMEBER THESE NAMES.

Here comes the big daddy: Actual Calculus. This course mostly discuss about Differentiation, from first principle, to all the rules, to implict differentiation, and finally related rates and optimization. It's honestly kinda fun to work around the problem, but unless you're a psychopath like me, you might not like it as much.

One more topic: Integration. There's honestly not a lot to talk about, only two main things to worry about: U-Substitution and fundemental theorem of calculus, and that's about it.

Overall, I do think as a 3-month course, it's a bit too much for most to handle, but if you are a psychopath who is curious about everything, I think you can have a fun time in this course. Personal view on content, B sounds pretty good.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Oh boy, we got a lot to talk about.

Professor Lam, good person. He's from Hong Kong, very good person. Something I like about him is that in lectures he always asks the right questions, for example when he was teaching L'Hospital rule, he would change the questions into other formats which might be difficult to understand at a first glance, but he would slowly explain how and why it would/wouldn't work. He helped me a lot into understanding how everything works, which has a pretty big impact on me.

Onto the next guy........, Mister Tommy, bad person, very bad person. He's also from Hong Kong, but it doesn't make him good. In his first lecture, I can already sense something is wrong. Firstly, WHY IS THE TA AN OLD DUDE? Secondly, his first sentence was "A function is not just x and y" which I THOUGHT he might be cooking. The food was fucking raw, he just pointed to a lot of like pure maths symbols, TO PEOPLE WHO DIDN'T TAKE M2 BEFORE. I ONLY KINDA UNDERSTAND WHAT HE WAS SAYING CUZ I SEEM THEM ON YOUTUBE, BUT THAT DOESN'T MAKE IT BETTER. Oh yeah another thing, I don't think he knows who the audience is. There was one thing he was proving trigo identities, and then he started using determinants to prove those identities? Let me rephrase it, he is using linear alegbra concepts to teach people WHO DON'T EVEN KNOW WHAT LINEAR ALEGBRA IS!!!! WTF??? And then in his other tutorials and lectures, I don't know whether it's a habit thing of what, after saying a bunch of gibberish, he would end the sentence with "that's it", like he for sure know the audience knows what's happening. God I hate this dude.

Overall, if you just wanna get a pass, just listen to Professor Lam, you don't need those lectures and tutorials from Mister Tommy, or another option is there are other TAs that can actually teach you something, like my friend really this Phyllis dude, highly recommend from him. Professor Lam, easy A; Mister Tommy, low D. The only reason he is not E is there are rare moments where he would say something that is quite interesting and not talk about in lectures, but unless you're trying to aim high grades, you don't need to worry about it. Speaking of grades.......
reviews.comment_grading:
Here comes the bias part. I heard from a lot of people that say this course is terrible and the grading is bad, but I guess I'm the lucky few who isn't really affected by it.

There are three main assessments, homework(10%), midterm(35%), and final(55%).

The mean of the homework is pretty high, around 90%, meaning if you want to have a safe pass, you have to get all the marks from the homework, the workload will be discuss more later.

Onto midterm, honest reaction, I thought it was pretty easy, feels basic even. But the statistics proven me wrong. The mean was 44.31 with a s.d. of 22.28, and I got 100. Bruh.

Final, I personally think they finally step up their games, the questions are much harder, and the statistics was shown to be true. The mean was 50.37 (s.d. not given), and I got a 94. Not bad I guess.

The total mean is 52.2, which I think it's B? I did get an A+ with a total of 96.7, so I honestly can't judge whether the grading is bad or not.
reviews.comment_workload:
Here's the thing, you're probably a science/engineering student, so you know you have other math courses to study. VERY IMPORTANT: START LEARNING ABOUT CALCULUS BEFORE LECTURES. Treat the lectures as review sessions. If you are able to do that, you will have a much better time understand what the professors are talking about. It might sounds difficult, but trust me, just use an hour or two at the end of the day to understand the basic concepts, when the lectures starts talking things that are more in-depth, you will have a good time.

For homeworks, apparently the questions are not so easy. You do need to spend some time on them, but you will learn a lot from them after trial and error.

For preparing midterm and final, here's a very dirty trick, instead of doing 1012 past papers, do 1013 past papers. They're basically the same course, but one of them is harder, and if you study harder past papers, you will be prepared a lot. No joke, the SAME questions were copied from 1013 to 1012, doing this helps a lot.

Overall, you do need to spend some time on this, or else you might easily fall behind. If you hate math, I would say C or D, but if you like math, I would say B, I honestly learned a lot.

reviews.author: Jacky_ng
reviews.title: Worst
reviews.comment_content:
This is an introductory course in one-variable calculus, the first in the Calculus I and II sequence, designed for students without HKDSE Mathematics Module 1 or Module 2. Topics include functions and their limits, continuity, derivatives and rules of differentiation, applications of derivatives, and basic integral calculus.

This course requires students to use 3 months to learn most of the things in DSE M2 syllabus which takes 2.5 years to finish. Learning this course will only let you hate calculus for the rest of your life.

The course also makes us regain the ability to calculate without using a calculator, especially question types that you originally could use calculator in HKDSE like quadratics.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching is good, he try his best to explain most of the complex concept to student with some example in class, but that example is far easier than the one you will see in webwork or exam.

The 50 mins tutorial lecture provided by TA explained concepts at a very fast pace, which made it hard to follow his pace. But the notes and exercise questions provided are easy to understand and the difficulty is similar to those you see on the exam.
reviews.comment_workload: Huge. You will have to spend a lot of time just to catch up on the course content if you have a weak mathematics background. I rely on online videos in YouTube or Bilibili to help me to learn. Even with a large amount of drilling of questions, you will still struggle with the exam.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Not only is his accent difficult to understand, but his teaching style may not be suitable for everyone. He assumes that you have some basic knowledge of calculus and focuses on teaching you how to prove formulas.

As a beginner, you may find this method unhelpful for understanding the material. In that case, it may be best to SKIP SKIP SKIP the lectures.

On the other hand, I found the tutor's notes and teaching style to be very helpful in MATH1012, along with resources such as YouTube. I strongly recommend blackpenredpen youtube channel which help me survive in the exam :)


Good Luck to all see till the end ~
reviews.comment_grading:
Two grading method

1) 0.3 mid term, 0.3 hw, 50 final
2) 0.1 mid term, 0.3 hw, 50 final
unlimited times

Even if you fucked up during the mid-term exam, you still have a chance to improve your grade in the final. Personally, I find the final exam questions to be more manageable overall.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload for homework is definitely not heavy. What you need is self-study, practice, and more practice!

reviews.author: YUpEp
reviews.comment_content:
Part of the DSE M2 syllabus is covered in this course. If you got good Maths results, it might not be that difficult for you to learn. You may get a lot of resources from YouTube. And it is recommended that you do more exercises and try to understand the concept behind it.
But I think the content is not that useful when you need to study phy1112. Better to study other M2 module before fall sem or during sem break

Week one:
â€¢ Numbers, inequalities and absolute values.
â€¢ Basic functions and graphs, composite
functions.
Week two:
â€¢ Exponential functions, trigonometric
functions.
â€¢ Inverse functions, logarithmic functions
and inverse trigonometric functions.
Week three:
â€¢ Tangent and velocity.
â€¢ The limit of a function, limit laws.
Week four:
â€¢ Continuity.
â€¢ Limits at infinity and horizontal asymptotes.
â€¢ Derivatives and rates of change.
Week five:
â€¢ Basic derivatives.
â€¢ Product and quotient rules.
â€¢ Derivatives of trigonometric functions.
Week six:
â€¢ Chain rule.
â€¢ Implicit differentiation, derivatives of
inverse trigonometric functions and logarithmic functions.
Week seven:
â€¢ Rates of change problems.
â€¢ Related Rates.
Week eight:
â€¢ Linear approximations and differentials.
â€¢ Maximum and minimum values.
â€¢ Midterm Exam.
Week nine:
â€¢ Mean Value Theorem.
â€¢ Derivatives and concavity.
â€¢ Lâ€™Hopitalâ€™s rule.
Week ten:
â€¢ Curve sketching.
â€¢ Optimization problems.
Week eleven:
â€¢ Anti-derivatives.
â€¢ Areas and distances.
Week twelve:
â€¢ Definite integrals.
â€¢ The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.
Week thirteen:
â€¢ Indefinite integrals and net change.
â€¢ Substitution rule.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Hu, Jishan is quite good at explaining the concept and tryna prove and finish the examples shown in the textbook detailedly. However, if you have learnt some, it is okay for you to skip the lectures, which are taught at a very slow pace.
The tutorial is good to attend. There are 2 tutors that I will recommend are  Hoi Sang KONG and Phyllis LIANG.
KONG Hoi Sang is also good at explaining the problems given in the tutorial notes. And in his notes, he had screened some 'useless' questions. You don't need to waste time on classviva:) Just finish the questions in his notes.
Phyllis' notes are good for you to clean the concept. Her lessons are fast-paced and you may get the feeling of having secondary lessons, which may be adaptable for you(?)

Feel free to go to math support center. Those tutors are really nice to solve your problem :)
reviews.comment_grading:
There was originally 1 grading scheme before the midterm. But there was another grading scheme after the marks of MT is released.(maybe because the mean of MT is shit)
This is not absolute grading.

scheme 1: homework 20%, mid-term test 30%, final exam 50%;
scheme 2: homework 20%, mid-term test 10%, final exam 70%.

My final didn't cover the part of integration and cover a lot on the L'Hopital rule. If you want to get full marks on the long question, you may tryna read the tutorial notes' answers and remember the format, they grade it strictly:)

My result:
Homework:100/100 (Mean:79.55/100)
Mid-term:70.5/100(Mean:33.91/100)
Finale:92/100(Mean:58.18/100)
Total: 91.45(Mean:62.09/100)
And I got an A in this course.
Seems 88% can get an A, 94% A+
reviews.comment_workload:
If you like Maths and you are willing to finish those exercises in tutorial notes, you will probably get a good grade.
Two assignments per month. You can finish it within 2 hours. Unlimited attempts so no worry.

reviews.author: Jack0001000
reviews.title: The first chapter of suffering in HKUST
reviews.comment_content:
Basic calculus, like the course title suggests.
Basic introduction like domain, set, trigonometry at the start, then differentiation and its applications all the way until after midterm, and at last (very) basic integration. This semesterâ€™s final exam cuts integration out completely because of the midterm disaster, more details in the grading section.

The course design is quite good, with 2 lectures, one supplementary lecture (taught by TA) and 1 tutorial each week,
reviews.comment_teaching:
TU is a definite piece of evidence that an extremely talented person in maths may not have any talent in mathematics education. He tried to teach us who never had any experience in calculus delta-epsilon proof in the 2nd week, and failed spectacularly. Iâ€™ve heard even the UG maths coordinator got involved to â€˜askâ€™ him to be more considerate of our maths level.

On top of this, he has very thick accent. It was very difficult to understand what he is trying to say. One of my classmates even made a whole list of words he pronounced weirdly, so thatâ€™s the only thing we can laugh about in this course I guess.

But if you want to hear about some of his redeeming qualities, he seems like a pretty chill guy outside of class time. He is willing to share some details of his earlier life if you ask in Mandarin. Also itâ€™s his first year teaching here, so his lack of experience is sort of expected.

If the prof is Yin, the TA Phyllis is the Yang, more respectfully known as the hand that gives MATH1012 students another life. Others have said enough, so Iâ€™m not going to repeat the details, just remember that tutorials are very important and that donâ€™t skip it unless you really need to.
reviews.comment_grading:
Curved grading.

The midterm is a nightmare, with the mean score being 30.XX out of 100, with â€˜most students in the 0-40 rangeâ€™. This  forced the introduction of 2 grading schemes:
1: 20% homework + 30% midterm + 50% final
2: 20% homework + 10% midterm + 70% final
The final exam is better, with a mean of 54 something. I guess they are more lenient in the final.
reviews.comment_workload: Light workload, with 8 homework on classviva spaced throughout the semester. Try your best to get 100% on all of these so your grade might be saved in the end. Also, you can get lots of voluntary exercise on this website, so get to work.

reviews.author: ifunmd
reviews.title: Written by a Jupas student who did not have calculus background
reviews.comment_content: Other reviews have provided all the details, so I'm not gonna repeat here.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I self-studied in the summer holiday which contibutes a lot to my A+.

DON'T expect that you can learn everything in this 4-credit course in just 3 months if you have not studied any calculus before, especially under the circumstance that Prof HU only likes to talk about proof with an uncomfortable accent(that's why he taught slowly and the majority think his teaching is worst).

Make use of any resources to prepare for this course before the course begin if you want to get A- or above (if you are not one of those math genius).

Tutorials are generally better than lectures though.

For me the overall teaching is B.
reviews.comment_grading:
In this semester two grading schemes are adopted.

Weights under scheme 1:
Hw 0.2 Mterm 0.3 Final 0.5

Weights under scheme 2:
Hw 0.2 Mterm 0.1 Final 0.7

The scheme with a higher overall grade will be automatically adopted.The reason for using two grading schemes is probably most of us were not doing well in Mterm. Mterm was more diffcult than the final from my perspective.

Worth noting that Intergration were taught but were not included in Final since Prof HU taught slowly.

There are unlimited attempts for assignments and only the highest grade of each one will be recorded.

For L1 scores please refer to the attachment.

I would have given the grading a C if there are no two grading schemes.
reviews.comment_workload:
One assignment every two weeks on Classviva.

The last assignment (intergration) was hard since Prof HU taught slowly so only 2 lectures and 1 tutorial are for teaching intergration. However the techniques required in HW8 were far beyond what he had taught in those lessons so I paid more efforts in it.

If you have no calculus background, you need to self-study before the course begin and do more extra exercises in order to get a good grade. This will result in a higher workload, of course. For people not aiming high, just do some extra exercises and you will get a B-range.

For me the overall workload is C.

reviews.author: zoeylam
reviews.title: Very difficult course
reviews.comment_content: just study from youtube
reviews.comment_teaching: I did not attend the lecture. But it has lecture video. And the professor has given some exercise for us but those exercises are totally useless.
reviews.comment_grading:
curve grading
mid-term mean is around 30%. Final mean is around 50%.
exam 10 mc, 8 mc are limit:)
I got a C- ( including hw) overall around 40% . Hopefully can pass:). It is because all my hw is 100% correct.
reviews.comment_workload:
8 hw in total
and the hw is 20% of the grading. Remeber to do it on 100% correct. It may determine whether you can pass or not.

reviews.author: CoffeeDrinker21
reviews.title: Written by a Non-JUPAS student with no Calculus experience
reviews.comment_content:
Week one:
â€¢ Numbers, inequalities and absolute values.
â€¢ Basic functions and graphs, composite
functions.
Week two:
â€¢ Exponential functions, trigonometric
functions.
â€¢ Inverse functions, logarithmic functions
and inverse trigonometric functions.
Week three:
â€¢ Tangent and velocity.
â€¢ The limit of a function, limit laws.
Week four:
â€¢ Continuity.
â€¢ Limits at infinity and horizontal asymptotes.
â€¢ Derivatives and rates of change.
Week five:
â€¢ Basic derivatives.
â€¢ Product and quotient rules.
â€¢ Derivatives of trigonometric functions.
Week six:
â€¢ Chain rule.
â€¢ Implicit differentiation, derivatives of
inverse trigonometric functions and logarithmic functions.
Week seven:
â€¢ Rates of change problems.
â€¢ Related Rates.
Week eight:
â€¢ Linear approximations and differentials.
â€¢ Maximum and minimum values.
â€¢ Midterm Exam.
Week nine:
â€¢ Mean Value Theorem.
â€¢ Derivatives and concavity.
â€¢ Lâ€™Hopitalâ€™s rule.
Week ten:
â€¢ Curve sketching.
â€¢ Optimization problems.
Week eleven:
â€¢ Anti-derivatives.
â€¢ Areas and distances.
Week twelve:
â€¢ Definite integrals.
â€¢ The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.
Week thirteen:
â€¢ Indefinite integrals and net change.
â€¢ Substitution rule.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I've literally paid 0 attention to lectures and attended 1 session of tutorial.Dr. Yang did say he won't be teaching us but could only provide examples on the very first lecture so I'll give him credits for being honest.

Instead I've used online materials to help me understand the concepts of calculus, Phyllis did give us notes on all topics which is quite useful. Unfortunately, I can't say her teaching really helped me.

Here's some of the materials I've used to learn Calculus:
Professor Leonard: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fYyARMqiaag&list=PLF797E961509B4EB5 (For clearing concepts)
Oscar Cheung: https://www.youtube.com/@oscarcheung718/featured (For question samples)
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is meh.
Grading scheme 1: Homework 20%; Mid-term 30%; Final 50%.
Grading scheme 2: Homework 20%; Mid-term 10%; Final 70%.
Homework average: 87.2/100; My score:100/100.
Mid-term average: 28.47/100; My score: 22/100.
Final average: 59.95/100; My score: 76/100.
My overall mark under scheme 1: 64.6/100.
My overall mark under scheme 2: 75.4/100.
Grade: B

Mid-term contents: Limits, Derivatives, Implicit differentiation.
Final exam contents: Limits, Optimization, L'Hoptial's rule, Curve sketching
reviews.comment_workload:
2-3 Homework per month, 16 questions on average.
Questions could be difficult for someone who haven't touched calculus at all, but most of the solutions can be found online. Feel free to ask your lecturers questions on homework you don't understand, they even give you answers sometimes lol.

reviews.author: tianyu
reviews.title: simple calculus
reviews.comment_content:
Simple one-variable calculus. There are four parts:
Limit
Derivative
Antiderivative
integration
Remember their definition and you are going to get an A.
reviews.comment_teaching: N/A. I didn't attend any tutorials or lectures. But my prof would upload all lecture notes to the canvas- including all concepts you should learn - for you to revise. The notes are thorough so I still give a B.
reviews.comment_grading:
2 schemes :
///Hw:20% Mt:30% Final:50% ///
///Hw:20% Mt:10% Final:70% ///
Probably because the mean of the midterm is too low.

///Hw mean:18.32/20 me:20/20
///Mt mean:30.68/100 me:96/100
///Final mean:56.91 me:99/100
///overall mean:60.82 me:98.9
letter grade A+ not surprised.

Although the mean is very low, the exam is pretty easy.
The midterm duration is 2 hours and I left 1 hour earlier; I made a careless mistake on the step so only 96.
The Final duration is 3 hours and I finished the paper within one hour; many people left when the TA allowed us to leave.
This year the final does not include integrations;
here's a tip: learn the Lhosipital rule, mean value thm, and also Tylor expansion. You can KO all the limit questions in a few seconds.
reviews.comment_workload: only 8 hw; each of them takes one hour to finish. Consider that each hw gives you two weeks, the workload is low.

reviews.comment_content:

Hi I'm Saul Goodman, did you know that you have rights? 1012 says you don't
reviews.comment_teaching:
Speaking from the experience of being in L3: Tu Xushan has the hardest accent I've ever heard and I couldn't understand what he's trying to say; Like, he pronounces Theta as "c-tart", and mean as "meme", yeah, go figure

If you have friends in 1013, go to sit their lectures instead, you'll probably learn more from there along with YouTube University (Check out Oscar Cheung's playlist from SSci, he's pretty good)

The only saving grace for 1012 is that they have tutorial sessions by TA's that literally teach better than the professors, Phyllis Liang is great and her tutorial sessions are worth going to unlike the actual lectures
reviews.comment_grading:
Per the words of Tu Xushan in the group chat after the midterm grade was released: "most students are between 10-35%, and L1-L4 are almost the same"

Marks in the midterm are distributed as 40% MC and 60% LQ, 4 MCQs worth 10 marks each, and 3 LQs worth 20 marks each, literally get lucky with 1 MCQ and you'll already be ahead of a good number of people

Midterm mean for L3 is 29.2/100, SD 24, the distribution curve was literally an L shape, this is accurate because what we take here at 1012 are L's and no W's. Like wtf is this LOL
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is okay, one assignment every 1-1.5 weeks with each having 15-19 questions, though some of them can be a little mind boggling

Just know for a fact that the questions between assignments compared to the midterm are from different dimensions

Waltuh, put your midterm away Waltuh

reviews.author: jas333
reviews.comment_content: I did not study m2 at secondary school so the content of this course was completely new to me. I had lv5 in hkdse maths so i would say my foundation in maths is not too bad. Nevertheless, i still find this course rather challenging. It is mainly about functions, derivatives, limits etc.
reviews.comment_teaching: The accent was difficult to understand and the pace was too fast for me. I gave up going to the lectures and studied this course on YouTube 10 days before the final exam.
reviews.comment_grading: I did not work hard and did not study until the final exam does come. I got around 50% in the final, did not complete all the hw and got b- in the course.
reviews.comment_workload: hw every week in the form of mc or short questions. It is a little bit too much for me because the questions are challenging and there are many sub questions under each question.

reviews.author: yoll
reviews.comment_content: The content is about basic calculus. The content is not hard in general, if you learned M1 or M2 before it is easy for you to handle this course.
reviews.comment_teaching: It is hard to understand his accent. I often miss the point in his lesson cuz i don't understand what he is talking about.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading for the course is not good.
reviews.comment_workload: You have to do the homework every week. There are 10-20 questions in each homework. There is no mid term exam in this course, so the workload is not too heavy.

reviews.author: gcaiaa
reviews.comment_content: Professor will upload the materials needed for the class to canvas in advance. Homework is once a week with unlimited attempts.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor will recommend some textbooks to you in the second class. Most of the time the professor still teaches according to his own teaching plan but it would be better if you can preview with a book recommended by the professor.
reviews.comment_grading: My homework is  full marks and I remember that I got 80% of my final exam. Finally, my total score is a A-.
reviews.comment_workload: It's easy to be handled even for students didn't take M1 or M2 in high school. In my mind, most of the questions are chosen to fill in the blanks. I'm not sure if the offline course assignments are still like this. Each assignment won't take you more than an hour per week.

reviews.author: ab_32431
reviews.title: Boring and don't take this course in Spring semester if you can
reviews.comment_content:
as this course is held in spring semester usually for fail students, so it has only one timeslot for MATH1012 and MATH1013 together. Hence, MATH1013 stuff also will be taught in this course. So, it is better to join in other semester to study without MATH1013 students.

syllabus is uploaded
reviews.comment_teaching:
He teaches in a slow pace, boring note taking
very messy notes in my opinion, difficult to follow up

always say "are you listen to me? why i did that wrong and nobody finds it out"

In addition to online teaching(with long teaching hour each week, lecture+tutorial  needs 2hour20min A DAY!!), the lesson is so boring

and he always teach that "knowing the basic is good", and he will explore in his maths dream and seems that not following the teaching materials sometimes, and say "i want you to prove the formula, exam i will give u some question to prove"

finally i think there is no prove question at all, as all are MC lol, and i dont want to prove any maths thing plzzzzzzzzzzz

so i think no matter you study this math course or other math course, stay away from him, otherwise plz self study online
reviews.comment_grading:
36% webwork, quite a lot of exercise (abt 15-16ex, each 10-18 questions) but unlimited attempt

most annoying is webwork is done in tutorial lesson, me really question mark(you need to open camera and do the webwork "home"work)
even though webwork also provides about 10 ex for u to practice(each about 30q), and u can actually done the hw on other place first without submit the ans outside tutorial time(and copy and paste during tutorial), still think it is ridiculous to open camera for doing webwork "home"work

64% final exam, all MCs in canvas
cannot return to precious page after finishing 1 q

mean is 6x%, i get mean and have C+
------
0%attendance
it counts attendance in tutorial and lecture(even though dont count grading), and requires you to open camera, if you dont do so then attendance wont be counted
if number of absent is more than 4, F grade is given
---
0% mid term exam
all MCs
just chill for this, just for lecturer to see students' progress, so the mean is quite low (around 8/20)
-----
0% admission test
when u enroll this course in spring sem, most stu should be fail in fall.
so this test is organised in the beginning of the course in order to test ability if u still hv dse maths level to study the course (not much m2 stuff, me also full mark in that test)
it claims to be MC, but only some are MCs
most are fill in the blanks(numbers)
total 18q around i think
if u failed, i think u cannot continue the course

---
*maybe the only gd thing is dse calculator is allowed in this semester course, including admission test, final and mid term but that means questions can be difficult
open book is also allowed in final and mid term, but haha, u think u really hv time find materials?
reviews.comment_workload:
it depends, if u really study hard, i think webwork's workload is okay, but for somebody it can be harsh, esp some questions can be hard for original MATH1012 students (unlimited attempts)
but i really not paying too much effort to this course, so i accept this grade anyway

reviews.author: Joannew
reviews.title: You have to take this anyway, just take it.
reviews.comment_content: Just see other reviews, they have the details and I am not going to repeat them. Mostly the DSE M2 things. The content will be more the Math 1003 in case you are considering choosing which one. For SSCI and SENG ppl, sorry you don't have a choice.
reviews.comment_teaching: I just have the first three lessons and never listen again. I don't know how is the teaching. Although is in mixed mode, my session is full online mode and so you know why I am not having lessons.
reviews.comment_grading:
75% Final
25% HW
I got full in hw and 46/100 in the final.
I only get 4 in DSE math. I am so satisfied with my result lmao.
Eventually, get a B+ as the mean of the final is 43 sth.
Not in absolute grading, which is much better than Math 1013.
Kind of good grade as the course even has a better grade than my lang course.
reviews.comment_workload:
HW every week, if as lucky as me to have a friend know how to do them, it is not a problem at all. If not, just try your best to do all of them, unlimited attempts eventually can get the answer.
For the final, I never listen to the lecture and study myself for around 1-2 weeks before the exam, at least I can understand some questions and write sth on paper. Don't learn this from me, if you want a better grade, please try to listen to the prof or watch youtube for the concepts. Especially SENG ppl, you may have to continue your journey on Math in 1014, you should really know how things work here in order to not suffer that much in 1014.

reviews.author: evvon
reviews.title: Give up. If you want to swap to Xie Peng, I encourage you. Give up.
reviews.comment_content: Dunno, I just attend the first few lessons and after all, I just watch youtube. Insane UST wants you to learn the DSE m1/m2 3-year syllabus in one semester.
reviews.comment_teaching: His accent is SHIT, totally SHIT. This is the main reason why I give up attending lectures. You know when his accent is distracting me from focusing on what he wrote.
reviews.comment_grading: Changed to relative grading, So good. Normally get B+, but it will be poor if it is absolute grading,
reviews.comment_workload: Low workload, One assignment per week, and unlimited attempts before the deadline.

reviews.author: Emmmaaa
reviews.comment_content: The teaching is satisfactory yet the whole course is so hard. If you are not really confident in mathematics, please spend more time in this course. You have to pay more effort in studying the relationship between numbers and especially differentiaion.
reviews.comment_teaching: He teaches not really bad but he was so annoying during exams. He called everyone's names continuously and this disturbs me. It's not possible for me to mute his mic as he might have important announcements. Yet, the tutorial is quite useful I think when many people got great improvements after attending them.
reviews.comment_grading: His grading is quite fair even though I have got poor grades in his course.
reviews.comment_workload: Homework every week and this is quite annoying when you know nothing about maths.

reviews.author: melodyloi1011
reviews.comment_content: It was very hard for students who know nothing about calculus. It was definitely not basic. The tutorials were way more useful than the lectures. But, no attendance was required for both lectures and tutorials. You could catch up by watching videos.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teacher taught with no passion. He spoke in such mono tone that I just attended one lecture in the whole semester.  However, the teaching assistant was quite good. She taught very clearly and neatly. Her notes were quite tidy and useful.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading was somehow good because even I failed the final, I still didnâ€™t get C range. As long as you have done all your homework, you could guarantee some basic marks. By the way, there was no mid term. So the final and your homework mark basically determined your whole grade of this course.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was just fine because there was just one homework on WEBWORK every week. The homework contained about ten questions each and with unlimited attempts. A good way for students who were bad at maths to earn marks.

reviews.author: Ian1017
reviews.comment_content:
This is an introductory course in one-variable calculus, the first in the Calculus I and II sequence, designed for students that have not taken HKDSE Mathematics Extended Module M1 or M2. Topics include functions and their limits, continuity, derivatives and rules of differentiation, applications of derivatives, and basic integral calculus.

However in my opinion, this course is definitely not in beginner's level. I had never learnt M1/M2 before and I couldn't understand anything during class, even my friend who had studied M1 during DSE couldn't loll.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Originally I was in Avery's class. His class was super boring as he was just copying his notes and wrote them on the whiteboard to teach us.
Then I swap to the same session as my friend's, which was taught by Qian. His accent was quite difficult to understand so basically me and my friends study by ourselves by looking up videos on YouTube, and we believe this is the best way.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading was fine, at least there were online assignments which you can try hundreds and thousands of times to get the correct answers. Yet the mid term and final exams are difficult for me.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload was fine. Remember to try to answer the online assignments until you get the correct answers to get the full marks out of it.

reviews.author: Jane Swift
reviews.title: Good if you like self-learning
reviews.comment_content:
The book is J. Stewart, â€œCalculus Early Transcendentals,â€  7th ed.

1 Number, inequalities and absolutes (Appendix A), basic functions and graphs,
composite functions (1.1, 1.2, 1.3)
2 Exponential functions (1.5), trigonometric functions (Appendix D), inverse functions,
logarithmic functions, inverse trigonometric functions (1.6)
3 Tangent and velocity (2.1), the limit of a function, limit laws (2.2, 2.3)
4 Continuity (2.5), limits at infinity and horizontal asymptotes (2.6), derivatives and
rates of change (2.7)
5 Basic derivatives (2.8, 3.1), product and quotient rules (3.2), derivatives of
trigonometric functions (3.3)
6 Chain rule (3.4), implicit differentiation, derivatives of inverse trigonometric
functions and logarithmic functions (3.5, 3.6)
7 Rates of change problems (3.7, 3.8), related rates (3.9)
8 Maximum and minimum values (4.1)
9 Derivatives and graphs (4.3), Lâ€™HÃ´pitalâ€™s rule (4.4)
10 Curve sketching (4.5, 4.6), optimization problems (4.7)
11 Antiderivatives (4.9), areas (5.1)
12 Definite integrals (5.2), the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus (5.3)
13 Indefinite integrals and net change (5.4), the substitution rule. (5.5)
reviews.comment_teaching: really bad, I didn't listen to him after a month. no use at all, so I end up self-learning.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework: 25%, final examination: 75%
fair, I did not get full mark in homework, and got 90/100 in final, end up A+.

The homework has unlimited chances before the ddl, I miss the point because of forgetting to do it.
reviews.comment_workload: light, the available time is enough.

reviews.author: wave
reviews.comment_content: The content is similar to what you learnt in high school. The content includes functions, graphs, integrals, inequalities, and derivatives.
reviews.comment_teaching: I can hardly understand what the instructor is saying as I find his accent hard to hear. As a result, I didn't come to any lectures or tutorials. It's better to study with your friends. I understand more from my friends. The attendance is not taken so I think the lectures were just a waste of time.
reviews.comment_grading: I think the grading is a bit of a gamble as it only includes the homework and final exam for the final score. If you choke on your final exam, your grade will drop as 75% of the final score is taken from your final exam. I did all the homework and I did well in the finals. I got A-.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is very light as there are only 9 webwork excercices you have to do in 1 term. I always did it with my friends and it usually take 2 hours to do as the questions are sometimes tricky. The workload is extremely light for a 4 credit course.

reviews.author: Darryl
reviews.comment_content:
This is an introductory course in one-variable calculus, the first in the Calculus I and II sequence, designed for students that have not taken HKDSE Mathematics Extended Module M1 or M2. Topics include functions and their limits, continuity, derivatives, and rules of differentiation, applications of derivatives, and basic integral calculus

The course itself is not particularly hard and you can study the entire course by yourself

reviews.author: JHstudent
reviews.comment_content:
This is an introductory course in one-variable calculus, the first in the Calculus I and II sequence, designed for students that have not taken HKDSE Mathematics Extended Module M1 or M2.
Mainly include functions and their limits, continuity, derivatives and rules of differentiation, applications of derivatives, and basic integral calculus.

People never study M2 in H K D S E may find it challenging.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Accent not available to understand clearly
Most of the students skip lessons as attendance is not recorded

Tutorial is fine but very easy
One of the lessons is just teaching how to name angles and what is sine cosine tangent
reviews.comment_grading:
No midterm Exam
25% Webwork
75% Final
As there is no midterm exam so final exam just determines your grade
Calcalator is not allowed in final exam
reviews.comment_workload:
Webwork nearly every week
but have unlimited times of attempts so trial and error will do for most of them
Some of the questions in webwork are really quite challenging and may spend plenty of time on it but better finish it because web work conttributes 25% of the total grade

reviews.author: GiRange
reviews.title: Much effort is needed
reviews.comment_content:
Most DSE M2 stuff but not include all.

<Week>
<1> Number, inequalities and absolutes (Appendix A), basic functions and graphs,
composite functions (1.1, 1.2, 1.3)
<2> Exponential functions (1.5), trigonometric functions (Appendix D), inverse functions,
logarithmic functions, inverse trigonometric functions (1.6)
<3> Tangent and velocity (2.1), the limit of a function, limit laws (2.2, 2.3)
<4> Continuity (2.5), limits at infinity and horizontal asymptotes (2.6), derivatives and
rates of change (2.7)
<5> Basic derivatives (2.8, 3.1), product and quotient rules (3.2), derivatives of
trigonometric functions (3.3)
<6> Chain rule (3.4), implicit differentiation, derivatives of inverse trigonometric
functions and logarithmic functions (3.5, 3.6)
<7> Rates of change problems (3.7, 3.8), related rates (3.9)
<8> Maximum and minimum values (4.1)
<9> Derivatives and graphs (4.3), Lâ€™HÃ´pitalâ€™s rule (4.4)
<10> Curve sketching (4.5, 4.6), optimization problems (4.7)
<11> Antiderivatives (4.9), areas (5.1)
<12> Definite integrals (5.2), the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus (5.3)
<13> Indefinite integrals and net change (5.4), the substitution rule. (5.5)

The content is not really hard since all the topics come from the DSE syllabus. If you are an engine student, you should try your best to study this course. Otherwise, you will get into trouble when studying math1014 and math 2011. If you are a science student, you are glad that this may be your last math course at HKUST.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Qian is good at teaching. Heâ€™s from the Mainland, but his accent is clear and understandable. He uses handwritten notes instead of PowerPoint during lessons. That's great since the peace of the lesson will not be too fast because he wrote the note during the lesson with us. If you are paying attention in class, it's not too hard for you to learn calculus from scratch.

As for my TA Henry, his voice is depressing; however, he taught us some shortcuts on doing questions. That's useful since it helped me to shorten the time on doing a question. He also did WebWork with us step by step during tutorial. Once you have any questions, you can ask him during tutorial or send email to him. He will answer you ASAP.
reviews.comment_grading:
Better than expected honestly
Relative grading
25% for Homework(WebWork)
75% for Final exam
-----------------------------------------------------------------
My grade:
Homework: 95.56% (Mean: 92.51%)
Final exam: 81% (Mean: 42.17%)
Grade: A
The grading is fair since it uses a relative grading system. One of my friends get 41% in final and get a B grade too. So, never give up!
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is moderate. There is 1 WebWork per week on average. However, more practice is needed besides WebWork for me since I am not good at math. If you are not good at math, I suggest you do all exercises from DSE M2 book like me. It will help you so much.

reviews.comment_grading:
Luckily this course does not have much non-local, so it is a good chance for you to get a good grade.

Not really hard to achieve A+ if you have studied partial fraction and by part (content in MATH1014) as you can see in the exam paper.

Kinda not absolute grading.
69+ A-, 75+ A, 84+ A+
Homework: Full
Exam: 97/100
=> A+
Mean 3x/100

Reasonable workload, one assignment every two weeks.
No midterm, but the exam.

reviews.title: This course will be your first course to skip lesson
reviews.comment_content:
This is NOT an introductory course in one-variable calculus, the first in the Calculus I and II sequence, 100% NOT designed for students that have not taken HKDSE Mathematics Extended Module M1 or M2. Topics include functions and their limits, continuity, derivatives and rules of differentiation, applications of derivatives, and basic integral calculus. This shit is not basic at all, its a forking torture, but its a must to take this course

1. Derive the inverse function of a given function
2. Limits (xcâ†’  and xâ†’ï‚¥)
3. To show the existence of a root by using the intermediate value theorem
4. Find the derivative from the definition
5. Chain rule
6. Implicit differentiation and tangent line
7. Rate of change
8. Locate the relative maximum and relative minimum (not at the endpoints)
9. Optimization problem
10. L'HÃ´pital's rule
11. Curve sketching
12. Indefinite integrals and definite integrals
reviews.comment_teaching:
Course mainly taught by a guy called XU, Zili, very boring, v.heavy mainland accent, can't understand anything he says, don't expect you can understand anything from him, Herman Yeung helps me more than him.
TA is Phyllis, a very nice guy I once chur her till 08:30 pm, will answer most of your questions, can find her if u don't know stuff in this course ask her.
reviews.comment_grading:
WebWork:25%
Final:75%

PLEASE, I BEG YOU, TRUST ME PLZ, I BEG YOU, DO YOUR WEBWORK, I know its a pain in the ass to do this work but it helps you a lot, you get 25% of the score, it helps you too much, you can fail your exam but still pass this course.

I get B- from this course, way higher than expectation.
WebWork:100/100
Exam: forgot/100 (But lower than 40)

Exam real hard recommend do paper, but it gets really time consuming, but don't waste all your time on this shitty course.
reviews.comment_workload:
When I done this course, I am finally free from this suffocation, this shit really shouldn't exist, its a grade killer, and time killer you are prevented to be a time management master from this course. First, you spent countless and countless hours doing webwork, you should find a group of dai lo to carry you. BTW most homework released before exam and other assignment.
Second, you waste most of your time on revision and doing past paper, since you won't understand a word from lecture, you end up spending most time on watching YouTube, and I need to credit Herman Yeung, professor dave and Organic Chemistry they really carry you through this course.

Thats it its a sad course :((((((

reviews.author: Milktea
reviews.title: JUST WATCH YOUTUBE MATH TUTORIALS
reviews.comment_content:
25% Webwork
75% Final Exam (no midterm)

The content is a bit much for people who have not taken M1 or M2 in DSE, but is manageable

The topics may seem unfamiliar and scary at first, but you will be fine once you understand the method of calculation

Topics covered in the final exam:
1. Derive the inverse function of a given function
2. Limits (xcâ†’  and xâ†’infinity)
3. To show the existence of a root by using the intermediate value theorem
4. Find the derivative from the definition
5. Chain rule
6. Implicit differentiation and the tangent line
7. Rate of change
8. Locate the relative maximum and relative minimum
9. L'Hopital Rule
11. Curve Sketching
12. Indefinite integrals and definite integrals
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teachers: Xu Zili, Li Jiayi (Regina)
- TL;DR: both are bad

The most useful math lessons are from mathvengers, which is compulsory for DSE students with level 3 or 4 in maths

Xu Zili: You won't hear what he is saying in the lecture hall cuz he speaks very softly. The fact that he has a heavy Chinese accent doesn't help. He overcomplicates every single topic and it is hard to keep up with his pace. I just skipped all his lectures cuz there is no need for attendance.

Regina: Regina teaches a small class every week. I could not hear her speak cuz she does not use a mic, she writes on a whiteboard with black markers that have no ink, could hardly see what she wrote. I just attended one lesson from her.

I just took the lessons from mathvengers, the year 2 students teach better than the teachers at UST

If you want to learn the topics efficiently, just watch youtube calculus tutorials
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading was better than I thought, even though it is a dog eat dog world

For the whole grade:
Mean (webwork): 90/100
Mean (final exam) : 37.34/100

I got the full mark for webwork and I had over 40 marks in the final exam, my final grade was B, it was better than I expected so I have no complaints. Big thanks to the organic chemistry tutor for the math videos
reviews.comment_workload:
There is too much webwork and the questions are way too hard

There are a total of 9 webworks and there is an average of 10 questions per webwork

Some of the questions involve questions related to physics and concepts that even M2 students find difficult

Try to do the webwork with your classmates or ask your friends to get 100% marks on webwork

reviews.author: wnYPXmoYnH3KH7
reviews.comment_content:
Limits, derivatives and a little bit of integration
Just Google Calculus I online for more info I believe it is the same pretty much everywhere
As someone who is not particularly good at math and has zero calculus background it is a lot to take in
reviews.comment_teaching:
Gave up on lectures after September lmfao
imo self study is more practical
Check out https://tutorial.math.lamar.edu/ and https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL0o_zxa4K1BWYThyV4T2Allw6zY0jEumv
You can also grab a pdf copy of the textbook + answers for more practice

Phyllis Liang is a pretty good TA + her notes are very useful (Google her if you don't have her)
Her sessions are worth going to
Make sure you understand the example problems in the tutorial notes they may appear in the final
reviews.comment_grading:
Better than expected honestly
Relative grading
Overall = Homework * 25% + Final * 75%

FYI:
Level 5 in HKDSE math (Didn't take M1/2)
Homework (Webwork): 100%
Final: 60% (Mean was like 30%-40% depending on which lecture session you were in)
Final grade: A-
reviews.comment_workload:
Around 1 Webwork per week
You can resubmit as many times as you want
As long as you have the patience to redo questions over and over again you will eventually get 100% for all of them

Just do it tbh (If you are really stuck try Googling the questions a bunch of them are copied from other universities there may be answers online)

If you have zero calc background, are not exceptionally good at math and still want a decent grade be prepared to spend extra time every week studying and learning on your own
(Actually try don't half-ass it if you want a good grade)

reviews.author: Regginton

reviews.comment_content:
As a IBDP SL maths student, this course is exactly like HL maths (AA not AI), tbh even if u dont know all the rules for the extended parts of derivatives or integrals dw, its all just chain rule and quotient rule (you just need to be proficient with the basics). Its not hard but also not easy.

course content:
1 Number, inequalities and absolutes (Appendix A), basic functions and graphs,
composite functions (1.1, 1.2, 1.3)

logarithmic functions, inverse trigonometric functions (1.6)

4 Continuity (2.5), limits at infinity and horizontal asymptotes (2.6), derivatives and
rates of change (2.7)
5 Basic derivatives (2.8, 3.1), product and quotient rules (3.2), derivatives of
trigonometric functions (3.3)
6 Chain rule (3.4), implicit differentiation, derivatives of inverse trigonometric
functions and logarithmic functions (3.5, 3.6)
7 Rates of change problems (3.7, 3.8), related rates (3.9)
8 Maximum and minimum values (4.1)
9 Derivatives and graphs (4.3), Lâ€™HÃ´pitalâ€™s rule (4.4)

literally All or fucken Nothing, the grading scheme is:

75% all in this one exam lol, yeah I initially thought it would be half MCQ and 3 long questions, but I guess I found out during the exam that it was 10 QUESTIONS AND 10 MARKS each, so when I opened my first reaction was "wtf, where are the mcqs"

idk the mean for HW, but honestly just do them dont be fucken lazy

literally 0, u either spend time doing it urself or teaching urself. use youtube whatever can help u understand the shit. Honestly I didnt know what half of the shit was until I didnt attend the lecture and teaching myself.

reviews.author: leon czolgosz
reviews.title: WELCOME TO HELL
reviews.comment_content:
Basic calculus my ass
Heard this is 2 years of M2 in one semester.

Week 1: Number, inequalities and absolutes, basic functions and graphs, composite functions Week 2: Exponential functions, trigonometric functions, inverse functions, logarithmic functions, inverse trigonometric functions
Week 3: Tangent and velocity, the limit of a function, limit laws
Week 4: Continuity, limits at infinity and horizontal asymptotes, derivatives and rates of change
Week 5: Basic derivatives, product and quotient rules, derivatives of trigonometric functions
Week 6: Chain rule, implicit differentiation, derivatives of inverse trigonometric functions and logarithmic functions
Week 7: Rates of change problems, related rates
Week 8: Maximum and minimum values
Week 9: Derivatives and graphs, Lâ€™HÃ´pitalâ€™s rule
Week 10: Curve sketching, optimization problems
Week 11: Antiderivatives, areas
Week 12: Definite integrals, the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
Week 13: Indefinite integrals and net change, the substitution rule

As an idiot who dropped out of M1 after learning limit (basically I know nothing about calculus) and got 4 in Math core (yes Iâ€™m stupid, I only got here because English weighting*2), this is too much for me. I survived by watching the zoom recordings at 1.5 speed, going to tutorial and supplementary class, and watching youtube videos. Definitely study before hand and do exercises.

I found these sites by Math TAs from earlier messages:

Mr Walter Chan:
https://sites.google.com/view/walterchan/2020-fall?authuser=0

Ms Phyllis Liang:
https://masxliang.people.ust.hk/
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Qian is ok. Heâ€™s from the Mainland, but his English is understandable. His notes are ok, with clear and very nice handwriting. He uploads them onto canvas afterwards after some classmates requested them. He includes a lot of math proof in his lectures/notes, which was confusing for an idiot like me.
As this is a zoom class, he wants everyone to be quiet and watch him write notes. He will answer questions in class if you ask, but someone asked him a question and he said it was too easy. I did not ask questions as I donâ€™t even know what to ask.
Unfortunately, I am a dumbass. I started crying when we got to sum-to-product rule of trigonometric functions or something and gave up and just watched the zoom recordings. And then I felt horrible because it was a bit disrespectful. Curse my Asian upbringing.
TA Henry Tsang is great. Taught us how to do webwork and explained stuff.

Just go to tutorials and supplementary classes. And watch youtube.
reviews.comment_grading:
25% webwork
75% final exam
FUCK YOU ASSHOLES HOW AM I SUPPOSED TO KNOW WHAT Iâ€™M DOING WRONG/POSSIBLE IMPROVEMENTS
AT LEAST FOR MID TERM IF YOU FUCK UP YOU CAN WORK HARDER IN FINAL
THIS IS LIKE DSE ALL OVER AGAIN
FUCKING SADISTS
Honestly, for webwork, I think everyone can get full marks, just go to the math support centre if you donâ€™t know.
Webwork:100% (Thanks Math support and other people)
Final Exam: 59% (plus 2 marks thanks to TA Henry) Mean: 42.17%
2 hours, 10 long questions this year, before there were MC.
As long as you do steps/draw diagrams/mention fundamental theorem of calculus/L Hopital/discoveries of other geniuses who have way too much time on their hands, you get points for trying.
Final Grade: 69.25% A- Mean: 54.75%
I really did not expect myself to do that well lmao

Unlimited attempts.

Acceptable. Just go to Math support. The TAs are great. Or use Symbolab or Wolfram Alpha or other online calculators.

reviews.comment_teaching:
-I only attended the first 2-3 lectures and skipped the rest. I wasn't interested in the class since I did calculus in high school. I would go watch them on triple speed before the final to make sure I am not missing anything.

-The instructor proves lots of theorems and identities, but I am not sure if it helps those with no calculus background. I prefer to start with explanations that are based on visualizations and intuition before doing the rigorous ones.

-Some of the study notes are useful.

-Phyllis LIANG is good and her explanations are always clear and helpful.

Webwork: 100%
Final: 94%
A+
reviews.comment_workload:
There are 9 homework problem sets on webwork. Some questions are tricky, and it is wise to allow a good time to solve them, though some of them are classical and repeated.

If you are planning to take this course, solve as many problems from the textbook as you can, or follow YouTube teachers, I recommend bprp.

fyi I got a 5** in core maths in HKDSE so take that as a reference.

rates of change (2.7)

trigonometric functions (3.3)

functions and logarithmic functions (3.5, 3.6)

reviews.comment_teaching:
Chan is a great professor, at least better than the other three. he got great local accent but you can definitely understand what is he saying.
his lesson is also pretty interesting. he uses three to four examples to illustrate the topics covered per lesson, you will definitely get a satisfactory grade if you attend all his lectures.

Phyllis is also a great TA. my friends who don't have Phyllis as their TA come take her class. she uses colour printed notes, using tons of examples to illustrate the concept, which makes my progress to be reasonable. you may ask her questions in cantonese, English or mandarin and she got a reasonable accent as a mainlander.
reviews.comment_grading:
this course originally uses absolute grading, but it somehow changed to relative grading which is such a good news to me for this semester. I will only get a A- under absolute grading.

Webwork: 100% (weighting 25%)
Final: 85% (weighting: 75%)
Total: 88.25% A+ Thanks God!

REMEMBER EFFORT PAYS OFF!!!!!
WHEN YOU LOVE MATH, MATH WILL LOVE YOU.
reviews.comment_workload: this course give you one webwork assignment per one to two week, if you don't do any additional exercises, workload will definitely be a a+. if you aim higher, you may do exercise in the textbook, they have adequate difficulty and suitable for you to clear your concepts, but it may result in a b- in workload

reviews.author: Raniaska
reviews.title: Very brief introductory course for calculus!
reviews.comment_content:
Basic Calculus concepts:
Functions
Limits
Differentiation
Integration
Just check the syllabus for the topics and teaching schedules.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor QIAN is a pretty decent instructor, you can clearly understand what he is saying and doing. With his hand-written notes filled with concepts and examples, I believe revising them a bit after each lecture is a good way to improve (which ironically I defo did not do that because I'm lazy :>). If you are paying attention in class, it's not too tough for people without any calculus background.

As for my TA Henry, his voice is depressing af but somehow makes me enjoy his tutorials and supplementary lessons because of it. He is very responsive to students' questions during classes and is actively trying to help us learn calculus. Sometimes his silly moves makes it even more enjoyable, I'm glad that I came across him.

Nothing related to HKUST but Khan Academy and Organic Chemistry Tutor helped me a lot to clear up calculus concepts so definitely go check them out!!
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading (from what I heard). I got 69/100 in finals and 77% in total (With all homework sets completed).

I must say I never thought my first ever grade will be an A- , considering that I have never studied HKDSE m2 but still managed to pull off a good grade is really surprising.

Final mean: 41.9/100
Total mean: 54.55%

It's pretty fair to say that if you completed all your homework sets on webwork, you would at least get C+ to B- , depends on how well your final exam is. I think the final is rather easier than the past papers, with 10 short / long questions only.

Grading method:
Homework: 25%
Final Exam: 75%
reviews.comment_workload:
New homework set on webwork every week with each having ~2 weeks before deadline. Some questions are easy while some are difficult. My TA asked which questions we needed help in every tutorial lesson and solved them one-by-one for us. So if you need help, just attend the tutorials (or search the answers on google if you want :> ).

Oh btw, this course allows unlimited attempts to submit homework answers so you could try as many times as you like before the deadline. :)

DSE M2 stuffs:

DERIVATIVES AND RULES
CHAIN RULE, IMPLICIT DIFFERENTIATION, AND DERIVATIVES OF TRIGO
RATE OF CHANGE
MAX&MIN
SKETCH GRAPH
INTEGRATION+RIEMANN SUM

When prof started teaching differentiation, I just fell asleep and skipped lessons. U only need to know how to do d/dx and integration in the final. I think it is a course for testing your self-discipline rather than math skills lmao.

Tips: GO WATCH YOUTUBE B4 FINAL, I recommend Herman Yeung and Khan academy for sure. Watch all the videos and playlists when u have a bus ride, a train ride, ready to sleep, basically just use all your space-time to self learn calculus.
reviews.comment_teaching:
C for CHAN
B for LIANG
A+ for TA TSANG, Henry Pak Yeung
I skipped lectures of prof since almost the end of differentiation and the start of integration. I only attended the Supp lecture (Henry) and tutorials of LIANG.

Personally, I think prof is not my learning style bcuz he focuses so much on proving things...... and sometimes go through the ppt too fast. How can I do implicit differentiation just after introducing what differentiation is ????? Man, I just know what is chain rule and power rule?? HOW?
But I've heard some of my friends suffered in the heavy Mandarin accent of other lecturers, they couldn't put up with it lmao. So maybe CHAN is fair la.

LIANG is good. She explained step by step at a fair pace. I like how she makes the notes simple, especially for limit, differentiation and integration. Idk if it is my problem or not, for trigo at the beginning, I just self-learnt it cuz I didn't understand what she was talking about.

TSANG, Henry Pak Yeung IS SO GOOD!!!!!!!
Makes funny and daddy jokes and tell us some interesting things in ust, and makes the math lesson in a good atmosphere. And he explained all the things so good, all in detail. Give us many useful tips for the final. Makes math fun even for a math idiot like me. Want to see him in 1014 next sem <3

reviews.author: ooga911
reviews.comment_content:
1. Functions
The first month covers the properties of different functions, finding domain and inverse functions
2. Limits
Then, the course move on to how to find the limit of functions, some important limits to remember and concepts of asymptotes
Note that L'Hopitals Rule will be covered after derivative
3. Derivative
This part cover basic rules of derivative, chain rule, how to find the related rate using derivative
4. Graph sketching
This part is hybrid of the part 1,2,3 mentioned above, it cover local&global extrema and how to sketch the graph for functions
5. Integral
Last part of the course is integral, which covers Riemann sum and indefinite& definite integral

As someone who failed this course once, I think the workload is heavy for people did not take m2 in DSE or people who are not good at maths like me.
You have to make sure you are clear about the concepts in every week, do not try to rush the syllabus within few days or you may fail the course
reviews.comment_teaching:
I attended first few lecture and skipped the remaining, the lectuer prove the theory and formula during lecture, you can choose to attend only if you are interested

Basically you only need to attend the tutorial of Phyllis, she will teach everything necessary for solving a question
reviews.comment_grading:
9 Homeworks on Webwork 25%
Final exam 75%

The mean for each homework is around 90%
And the mean for final is 42/100
reviews.comment_workload:
Around 1 homework per week, 10 to 15 questions in each homework
No mid term and attendance

Final is the big boss of this course, 75% for the whole course. Study the past papers and re do the webwork. then you can make it.

reviews.comment_teaching:
For Avery, since the course is really rush, he does not have time to explain or prove the law. However, it does not matter if you do not know how calculus comes from as the course does not request us how to prove the formulas in examination and homework. What you need to know is how to use different formulas to solve the question. That's it.  

For Phyllis, my TA. She is gorgeous, helpful and patient. Her tutorial note include a bunch of exercises captured from past exam papers. She explains every question in detail. Even though you do not what Avery is talking about, Phyllis can save your grade. I strongly recommend people who do not study calculus previously
attend her tutorial or watch all her videos at least. It would be really helpful.

If have questions with your homework, I suggest you ask phyllis in person or via zoom, because Avery is too smart, he does not why we cannot understand and Phyllis does not reply email frequently.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is quite good I think and fair.
no mid term

25 % webwork
(you should get all these mark, you can find the answer on google or ask TA)

75 % final exam
(open book, 19 MC out of 22 mark, only 2 of them are really hard, the other is not that hard)

My final grade, 25/25 webwork , 19/22 in final, I got  A  luckily.

I think it is pretty fair for students do not study M1 or M2 in DSE.
Avery is not a killer in my opinion.
reviews.comment_workload:
Medium

webwork every week and one final.

It is good to spend sometime to review and do all past papers

reviews.author: moni
