reviews.comment_content: You can check out the other reviews lol
reviews.comment_teaching:
Honestly, he isn't as bad as people make him out to be. Obviously, it's annoying to hear ummmm every 3 seconds but after some time you get used to it. He makes the lectures light-hearted and gives breaks and that's good enough for me.
That being said, when I studied for the exam, I just used the TA's notes cause she had way better example questions with more appropriate difficulty. Don't just rely on Avery's notes and examples, they're way too easy and that's coming from someone who is bad at maths.
reviews.comment_grading:
Not bad considering I crammed the whole semesters worth of stuff into 2 days (not recommended by the way).
Make sure to do the homework questions and get full marks on those, there are unlimited attempts and it can really boost your grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Pretty easy to do the homework. You can use photomath just to get the points and complete the work before the deadline but its highly recommended to go back and go through the questions to make sure you know what you're doing.

reviews.author: mc_cch
reviews.title: Hard to follow
reviews.comment_content:
"Basic" calculus   !?     lol
1. Trigonometric functions
2. Log
3. Limits
4. Derivatives
5. Integration

Be careful about the 'Derivatives' & the 'Integration' parts as they are quite difficult !

But you may become happy once you figured out the difference between 'log' and 'natural log' (e).

Note 1: L'HÃ´pital's rule is useful
Note 2: some people may get confused with the correct name of  L'HÃ´pital's rule. (NOT  The l'hospital rule, the hopital rule, l'hopital rule )
Note 3: HÃ´pital is a French word, which L' means 'the' in English
reviews.comment_teaching:
Pretty nice, as he is friendly and patient.

But he taught very fast, so for those students without Calculus background, you should pay attention to his every single step..............
Many students skipped his lecture because not everyone could follow what he was doing....................

For the TA (Walter Chan), I think his notes and course materials used in the lessons were quite useful, so please do not skip the tutorial lessons !

Both of them could understand English, Cantonese and Mandarin, so feel free to ask them.
reviews.comment_grading:
There was a special arrangement for this semester, so the final exam was done on Canvas.

HW: 25%   nice~~~ :)
Final: 75%

Grade:
HW: unknown %, as I didn't answer all the questions correctly
Final:  12/22 (54.5%)     (divided into 6 parts)

Overall:  B  (Fair la)
reviews.comment_workload:
You have to complete your homework (Webwork)  almost every week. They cover the basic mathematic and the topic you leaned. Some questions are EXTREMELY hard, so:
    1. Do form a Whatsapp/ Signal group
    2. Do send a email and ask the prof./ TA
    3. Do help your classmates
    4. Do go to the Math Support Centre (MSC) (Website: https://www.math.ust.hk/~support/index.html) as the TAs would offer assistance to you.

If you really want to get a good grade, you ought to get WELLLLLL prepared BEFORE the lessons. Because I couldn't follow well in the last two month. Also, I strongly recommend you to download all the materials form the TA's website (e.g. https://sites.google.com/view/walterchan/) and practice more before the exam....... Good luck!

Avery is a nice guy but doesn't know how to teach.

The lecture he made was is just showing the proof of every equation. Not very useful in clearing the concept or is any practical.

The English Avery spoke was remarkably horrible.

The TA is kind and patient. Please revise her note which is very useful if you don't want to fail. Highly recommended to attend her lecture, though her English is with some accent but is very clear.

reviews.comment_grading:
Webwork (25%)
Final Exam (75%)

The exam questions are way harder than the notes.

Difficult and time-consuming.

Please make sure you have all the question in the webwork correct, 100% in webwork is a lifesaver.

WolframAlpha is very useful, don't be afraid to use it.
https://www.wolframalpha.com/

Math 1012 with Avery as the instructor is basically semi self-teach, it takes much time to learn a new concept.

reviews.author: soysauce
reviews.title: alright for ex-m2
reviews.comment_content: I studied DSE M2 for form 4 (failed and dropped) and got basic concepts introduced in lectures with a bit of effort. Used the M2A New Century Mathematics book (for DSE) to go over course content. The book i used generally covers everything except for inverse functions (?). This course should be difficult to understand if you don't have any calculus background. For revision, find exercises that gradually go up in difficulty (from tutor's website etc.).
reviews.comment_teaching:
Inconsistent teaching pace. Professor tries to be slow for more difficult concepts but all concepts are difficult. Sometimes time is wasted at the beginning of the lectures to wait for people to come into zoom (~10mins to go from 30 people to 50 people)(attendance is not mandatory and zoom recordings are uploaded after each lecture). His class notes are uploaded. They are aesthetically pleasing and can help you understand what he said in lectures (I did not use them much).

TUTORIALS ARE USEFUL (had Walter Chan)
reviews.comment_grading:
Got A-. Grade from hw and final exam. I had 100% for hw. For exam got ~5pts above the mean for my exam group (students were split into 2-3 zoom meeting rooms for exam)(total ~24 marks).

Exam was split into 6 parts (a few questions for each part) and we got to see our marks after each part was submitted. No calculator allowed, questions were generally easier than hw. Good if you remember definitions and remember how to do basic math.
reviews.comment_workload:
All online work. Amount seemed moderate in the beginning but gradually spiraled out of control. New assignments created before the deadline of the previous one(s) ensure that you will always be in a state of worry. Always had some unfinished assignment at any given point during the semester. Last assignment was due on the last day of 'study break' with the previous assignment due just days before.

Questions can get pretty insane. At least we had unlimited attempts to get the assignments 100% correct. Achievable with patience.

Integrals

The content gets harder each week so you need to practice a lot to understand the content.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Avery's lecture is very hard to understand as he keeps saying "uh" constantly. I only attend the first lecture and I can't bear it so I didn't attend it for the rest of the course. However, the TA lecture and tutorial are super useful. My TA is Shixin Liang. She teaches each topic very clearly and her notes are neat and easy to understand,
reviews.comment_grading:
Webwork 25%
Final exam 75%
Grading is considered to be very harsh as the grades are decided mainly on final exams. Final exams have only 18 questions, each question worth 1-2 points totaling 22 points. Each question worth a lot and making a careless mistake can affect your score a lot. There are about 3 hard questions in the exam and the rest is pretty easy. The final exam is divided into 6 sections each 19 minutes so you have a lot of time in the exam, therefore, you should take your time and be careful to check your answer before submitting it.
Mine:
Webwork: Full score
Final: 17/22
Grade: A
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is moderate. There are about 9 Homeworks on the webwork to do throughout the course. You have unlimited attempts to do so you can easily get a full score on webwork. If you are stuck with the question, you can also join the math support centre zoom to ask questions.

reviews.author: pathetic
reviews.comment_content: The content is mostly part of M2 content, like differentiation, limits and part of integrations.
reviews.comment_teaching: I did not attend all lectures and tutorials but I do think attending tutorials helps more than attending lectures are the lecturer always just simply read out the ppt while the TA Walter Chan gives clear explanations and adequate examples are illustrated. Being able to learn the contents by yourself is important also.
reviews.comment_grading:
Webwork: Full mark
Final: 15/22
Grade: A-
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not much comparing with many other courses. There is only webwork homework regularly and the time period assigned for doing the webwork is more than enough. Doing the questions in the tutorial notes as revision is already enough to achieve a decent result in the final exam.

reviews.author: mickyli1117
reviews.comment_content: Limit, difficeration and integration
reviews.comment_teaching:
Avery:
The professor looks like a nice guy but his lecture is quite boring and difficult for us to learn. Maybe due to online-teaching mode, all notes are hand-written. There are no tidy lecture notes which make us difficult to revise.

Speaking of his pronunciation, it doesn't really matter but he always speaks "uh.. uh.. uh.. uh.. uh.. uh.. uh.. uh.. uh.. uh.. uh.. uh.. uh". quite funny lol.

Liang, Shixin:
A very good tutor, explain the concept clearly. In her lecture and tutorial, there are math exercises which she will do during the lesson. Tidy and easy to revise.
reviews.comment_grading:
25% Homework
75% Final Exam

For the homework, it is conducted in WebWork and you can have unlimited attempts. If you are willing to spend some time on it then you can get full marks easily.

For the final exam, since there is no mid-term exam, therefore, the exam weighs very heavy to your final grade. Each question can make a huge difference in your final grade.
Actually, it is not very difficult but seems like the overall performance is normal (not good, but many are marginal pass).
reviews.comment_workload: Light workload. There are total of 9 homework and on average you have at least 1 week to complete the homework.

reviews.author: Sonic12
reviews.title: Review of MATH1012
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1

Review of the concepts of functions and graphs.  (1.1-1.3; Appendix A.)

Week 2

Elementary functions.  (1.5-1.6; Appendix B-D.)

Week 3

Tangent and velocity; the limit of a function and limit laws.  (2.1-2.3.)

Week 4

Continuity; limit at infinity; limit definition of derivatives and rates of change.  (2.5-2.7.)

Week 5

Derivatives of basic functions; differentiation rules.  (2.8, 3.1-3.3.)

Week 6

Chain rule and implicit differentiation.  (2.8, 3.1-3.3.)

Week 7

Rates and related rates.  (3.7-3.9.)

Week 8

Maximum and minimum values.  (3.10, 4.1.)

Week 9

Derivatives and the shape of a graph; L'Hopital's Rule.  (4.3-4.4.)

Week 10

Curve sketching; optimization problems.  (4.5-4.7.)

Week 11

Antiderivatives; areas and distance traveled.  (4.9, 5.1.)

Week 12

Definite integrals; Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.  (5.2-5.3.)

Week 13

substitution rule.  (5.4-5.5.)

It's just an elementary calculus topic that you might have learned in high school.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Although the topics of this course are not that difficult, professor Avery Ching's teaching is so bad that if there's someone who is first to calculus it would not be helpful to attend the main lecture.

Instead, attend tutorial classes and participate in problem-solving actively. TA is very helpful and good at teaching. Just consider the tutorial class as the main lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
Webwork with unlimited attempts. Make sure to get a full score in webwork. If you don't know how to solve a certain problem don't hesitate to google it.

The final exam consisted of 6 parts and each lasted for 20minutes. Honestly, it was way too easy compared to the released past paper of this course. Just make sure to read problems and calculate things correctly.

Webwork(25%): 100%
Final Exam(75%): 20/22

Overall Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Just do your webwork assignment when it is out.
If you are good at math or familiar with calculus it would be not much of a burden.

However, if you are not good at math or first to this topic you'll have a hard time doing homework and preparing for the final exam.

To be more specific, if you are a student who came from a country that has a very competitive math curriculum(China, India, Korea, etc.) and good at all sorts of funky math stuff in your high school, don't worry you're the king of the class.

If you have undergone some international qualifications(ib, a-level, or SAT, etc.) or came from a country that has a relatively easy math curriculum, you are quite likely to say this course is difficult.

If you do feel this course is difficult, be diligent, and practice every day. Practice makes you perfect.

reviews.author: AzzAzAAzzzAza
reviews.comment_content:
This is the basic course of calculus, including inverse functions, limits, derivatives and integration.

If you have M2 lessons in secondary school, this course should be quite easy.
reviews.comment_teaching:
***I take this lecture during the period of COVID-19
Professor Avery has good knowledge in this area. However, the lecture is boring, and he seldom cares questions during the lecture (I guess he performs the lesson by I-pad and cannot see the questions). One time his screen is frozen, and he just keeps talking for half an hour, ignoring all the reminders by the students.

Regarding the content, the lecture gives proof of equations, which is, USELESS in the exam or your homework. You may join the lecture if you are curious about the proof but if you only care about the grade, you should join the Tutorials and lectures of the tutor. She gives a clear presentation and gives useful content.

For me, I skip all the lectures after the incident. I learn from Khan Academy during the lecture time. I only join the Tutorials and lectures of the tutor.
reviews.comment_grading:
Webwork: 25%
Final Exam 75%

***I take this lecture during the period of COVID-19

You have unlimited attempts for the webwork, so everyone is likely to get full marks in that part.

The Final Exam is all MCs. Open notes but no calculators are allowed. Better have lady luck smiles on you.

My case:
Final Exam: 14/22
and I got B+
reviews.comment_workload: Webwork is given around every 1-2 weeks. It takes around 1-3 hours.

reviews.comment_teaching:
I give E to the instructor. the instructor does not know how to teach the class. She just reads the slide mechanically without useful explanation. (FYI, her English is not that good, which makes me sleepy) So actually I skipped half of the classes and do self-learning.
I will give A to the TA. the TA Wa Fai CHAN is quite good though. He will give you guidance step by step. But I think the tutorial is not necessary, too.
reviews.comment_grading:
25% for homework
75% for the final exam.
no record for attendance and no midterm

The grade is not released right now but I believe I will get A+ for this course. I took full marks for the homework (100%) and final exam (22/22). The exam questions are really easy, so don't worry about the exam (past paper may help)
reviews.comment_workload:
I think the workload is relatively low. Most of the workload comes from the homework (totally about 100 questions for homework).
The best way to learn this course is by skipping all the classes and learn all the things by yourself.
5 days are enough for self-learning all the stuff (If you are a mainland student, I recommend you do not spend too much time on this course, then following the schedule below is enough; I am not sure if it is also available for local student).
1) the first 2 days: read the textbook and the slides, do some notes
2) the second 2-day duration: finish all the questions on the tutorial materials
3) the fifth day: do some summaries and check your notes.

reviews.author: yeet420
reviews.comment_content:
I took IB SL Math and while some of the concepts I've seen before it progresses in difficulty very quickly but if you stay on top of the content and try to practice weekly it should be manageable.

- Review of the concepts of functions and graphs.  
- Elementary functions.
- Tangent and velocity; the limit of  a function and limit laws.  
- Continuity; limit at infinity; limit definition of derivative and rates of change.  
- Derivatives of basic functions; differentiation rules.  
- Chain rule and implicit differentiation.
- Rates and related rates.  
- Maximum and minimum values.  
- Derivatives and the shape of a graph; L'Hopital's Rule.  
- Curve sketching; optimization problems.  
- Antiderivatives; areas and distance travelled.
- Definite integrals; Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.  (5.2-5.3.)
- Net change; substitution rule.  (5.4-5.5.)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor is kind, happy to answer students questions but her lectures are extremely boring as she just reads off the slides. Probably better off attending sessions with the TA and reviewing slides and textbooks on your own.


TA - Walter Chan
Best TA ever. 2 50 min lectures a week. Explains concepts very well and answers questions in a lot of detail. His notes and exercises are also very good practice problems to help you get familiar with the topics in this course
reviews.comment_grading:
25% Webwork online homework (unlimited tries)
75% Online MCQ final

Bad thing about not having a midterm is the first half of the course is much easier and majority of your grade ends up dependent on how well you do on the final.

Final exam was 6 canvas quizzes of 19 mins each and 3 or 4 marks. Part 1 opened at 9:30, part 2 opened at 9:50 and so on. This is a terrible system as I found the first 3 parts very easy and finished them in 8-9 mins each (with full marks) but ran out of time for the final 3 parts whereas in a normal exam you'd be able to make use of the extra time saved.

The final is also only 22 marks in total so every point is worth about 3.4% of your final grade which sucks lmao.

Overall I got:
Webwork: 100%
Final: 15/22 (Mean 13.4)

Final grade 76% and I got an A-. Seems to me the grade is fair in the end but the final being only 22 makes it very much up to chance.
reviews.comment_workload:
Overall workload is fairly light as there's no midterm (might change in future semesters) and only 10 homework assignments with about 2 weeks to do each. I'd recommend trying to find time to do a little bit of extra practice every week.

2x 1hr20min lectures a week with main professor
2x 50min lecture with TA

Huge amount of M2 content has to be familiarized within few months. If you do not have previous learning about calculus, you may need to depend more on yourself. Actually, it is quite time-consuming for the beginner to make clear the complicated concepts and apply them into the final exam.

Week 2

reviews.comment_teaching:
For Zhang, her teaching style is quite mediocre and boring. But she should be much better than Avery Ching. Her powerpoint slides can help me make clear the theorem of different M2 concepts. She can also give me an immediate email reply with clear answer when I have some problems about exam preparation. Her performance may thus be moderate.

For Walter Chan, I just want to say a big thank to him. His note, tone and teaching style can basically eliminate most of my misunderstanding of those complicated content. His notes also highly focus on practical side, which provide many chances for effective practice. If you just study and revise those notes, getting B+ is possible.
reviews.comment_grading:
Webwork 25%
Final Exam (online mc) 75%

Those 25% should be taken easily as long as you are willing to spend time into webwork by chegg, your friends, other online resourses, or just your own calculations. The unlimited attempt mechanism does really help me a lot, especially in the situation of getting a ungood exam result.

For the online exam, the difficulty is a bit lower as it is a open book exam. However, some of the questions were still quite demanding for student ability. So, don't think that it was too easy.
reviews.comment_workload: As I said before, this course is crazy for the Calculus beginner. The only way to escape from the fate of fail is practice. Only practice can make you know that you really understand the concepts. For webwork, its workload just depends on your way to get rid of them. Although hardworking may not help you get A grade, at least it can prevent the re-take of this course. Believe me, you don't want to face Avery possibly again.

limits

Avery ching is a boring lecturer. Relatively clear pronunciation, but spends a lot of time on boring, useless and irrelevant proofs of theorems. There are also very few examples in his lecture. Not worth attending. Skip the lectures and do something more meaningful

However, the tutorials offered by the TAs are quite good. Clear and concise explanation of questions which are like the actual exam.
reviews.comment_grading: Ok la

reviews.author: ustisfun
reviews.title: Self-learn and being proactive is compulsory, don't rely on prof
reviews.comment_content:
As is known to all, this course covers basic calculus concepts, namely limits, derivatives (optimisation, rates) and integrals. Elementary topics such as trigonometry and functions are also to be discussed.

The content itself is quite difficult to consume for students with zero M1/M2 background like me. Yet, if you are willing to do more exercises provided by TAs, I'm sure it won't be too overwhelming for you.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The 'E' is for the all-mighty Avery. To do him some justice, he seems like a kind guy. But you don't need to attend Avery's lessons because attendance is not counted. Another main reason is that his lectures are subpar, and his notes are utterly messy. He provides proof for each equation which are unnecessary and time-consuming, and I'm sure you have all seen his bad comments everywhere, whether of UST space, LIHKG or goop. Many people complain that he speaks ~10 'uuuhhhhs' in each sentence, but I don't think it really matters, because he's in MATH department, right?

I strongly suggest you revise TA's notes, which are neat and useful. For starters, you can see Phyllis Liang's notes, which can be found by searching her name on google. As for more question types, you can check out Walter Chan's notes, which can also be found on his google site.

btw, although Phyllis' accent is mainland-ish, her notes and lectures are highly useful, so do attempt (personally, I'm from Phyllis' group. She teaches in a slower pace which I like); Though Walter speaks in a prompt manner, he is experienced and I often find him during MSC hours because it's better for me to ask in Cantonese. Two great tutors that I strongly recommend if you are eager to improve.
reviews.comment_grading:
Got an A eventually.

webwork 25%
finals 22 marks ->  75%
However I have to point out that the percentage distribution is super shit. It is basically an all-in finals course.
reviews.comment_workload:
First off, don't be scared by the credit that this course carries, because it is not accurate (some 2 credit courses are so chur)

The good thing for 1012 is that the online homework assignments, which is done in a system called webwork, allows students to have unlimited attempts, while 1013 only has 5 attempts per question. Thus, you should get a full 25% if you do it.

Why I gave the workload a C is that it requires time to get to know the concepts of different topics. A good way to do it is to review TA's notes, which are listed in the 'teaching' section above.

If you have any questions, feel free to ask! Glad to help

reviews.author: k3v1nnoh
reviews.comment_content: This is an introductory course in one-variable calculus, its the first one in the two of the Calculus I and II sequence, it is for the students that do not have taken HKDSE Mathematics Extended Module M1 or M2, or IB Maths HL. It include functions and their limits, continuity, derivatives and rules of differentiation, applications of derivatives, and basic integral calculus.
reviews.comment_teaching: There are multiple of teachers and they differ a lot
reviews.comment_grading: I think as long as you are good and experienced in maths it wont be too difficult for you
reviews.comment_workload: Homework everyweek.

reviews.author: Saber Athena
reviews.title: å†‡è®€éM1/2æ—¢å…¥é»è¼ä¸€è¼
reviews.comment_content:
=To Freshmen=
  If you are reading this, it means that you are new to UST and this is likely to be one of your first courses here.
  It is easy to be overwhelmed by the new teaching style.
  It is very important to realize that the teaching quality in HKUST will be nothing like what you have experienced in your secondary school. There will not be people like DickHui or Koopa Koo to help you with your Math. If you rely on the lectures/tutors alone, you will die.

=Contents=
  Covers topics from absolute value, to limits, to differentiation and ending with integration by substitution.
  A lot of the contents are overlapped by HKDSE M2.
  Most of the contents covered in this course, like L'Hopital's Rule and limit to infinity, are direct prerequisite to MATH1014 (Which, if you haven't already realized, is what you will have to take next semester). It is important that you build up a good foundation or else you will die in 1014 (If you haven't already died in 1012)
reviews.comment_teaching:
=Zhang LuChan=
  I don't like criticizing people but her teaching quality is just really poor. It is really difficult to learn anything from her lectures. She reads directly from the powerpoint and makes no effort in explaining the concept. Trust me, you are better off reading the textbook yourself.
  People blame her mainland accent. But having an accent is really not the problem. Her English, though not perfect, are perfectly understandable. The main problem is the lack of passion in teaching.

=Walter Chan=
  Best fcking TA in the world. I mean it.
  Gives good lessons, Genuinely useful. He allows me to understand most of the concepts in the course. Very patient when answering student's questions. You can find him in MSC and ask him if you want to.
reviews.comment_grading:
=Exams=
  The midterm is slightly easier. It contains some typical questions like those you will encounter in Walter's exercise.
  The Exams are not the same. They contains extremely difficult questions, some you have never seen before.
  The Grading is not as bad as 1013 or 1014.

=My Grade=
WebWork: 100% (ish)
Midterm: 42/45
Finals: 10/15
Grade: B+
Meh.

(Reference: DSE Math Core 5*, Never taken M1/2.)
reviews.comment_workload:
There will be heavy workload, there is no questions about it.
  Accept the fact that many students in this class have studied calculus before (e.g. They took it in high school and dropped it.) Many students also have friends to help them with their Maths (Which you don't).
  You cannot get good at Maths in a few days. And you cannot expect to get a good grade if you start preparing a few days before the Exam.
  The only way to survive this is to go to Herman Yeung's channel and watch as many videos as possible. They will provide you with a good understanding of the concept allow you to deal with the difference types of problem. You can also check out Organic Chemistry Tutor or Khan's Academy's videos, although they tend to be on the easier side.
  Work of warning: Integration is very difficult to understand so prepare AT LEAST 1 month before the exam if you are seeking an A range.
  I don't really recommend reading the textbook as the style of writing is boring and technical. You will get confused and lost easily (Although the textbook proves to be pretty useful in 1014)
  Doing exercises is a must. You can start off by doing Walter Chan's exercise (Or those provided by the other tutors). You can also go do those in ä¸­å¤§å‡ºç‰ˆç¤¾'s M2 textbook IF YOU HAVE TIME. Try to not spend too much time on one specific topic.
  Lastly, go find Walter Chan for help if you have any question.

-Saber Athena

reviews.comment_teaching:
Terrible
His english... is it even english?
his chinglish is SO hard to understand.
I went to the first few lectures, did not understand a thing he said, and he gives out these useless definitions e.g the definition of a line, graph, and function.
USELESS
WHY COULDNT HE JUST GET STRAIGHT TO THE POINT
After attended 3 lectures, I stopped going, and just went to the tutorials.

My tutor is quite good, she explained things clearly and her notes ARE AMAZING!!!! basically only relied on her notes to revise. Her notes had basically all the examples. I also asked a friend to help teach me basically everything as well.

so basically, ignore lectures and just go to tutorials. get someone to teach you if you can.

got B in the end

reviews.author: averychingrocks
reviews.title: One of UST's easier courses *FINAL EXAM ATTACHED*
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1 Review of the concepts of functions and graphs. (Basically pre-calculus knowledge - high school stuff but know the fundamentals)
Week 2 Elementary functions
Week 3 Tangent and velocity; the limit of  a function and limit laws
Week 4 Continuity; limit at infinity; limit definition of derivative and rates of change
Week 5 Derivatives of basic functions; differentiation rules.  
Week 6 Chain rule and implicit differentiation.
Week 7 Rates and related rates.
Week 8 Maximum and minimum values. (Critical Points)
Week 9 Derivatives and the shape of a graph; L'Hopital's Rule.  
Week 10 Curve sketching; optimization problems
Week 11 Antiderivatives; areas and distance travelled
Week 12 Definite integrals; Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.  
Week 13 Net change; substitution rule

The content was very doable since I learnt more than half of it in IB SL Math so I only had to study Limits, L'Hopitals Rule, Fundamental Theorem of Calculus and Riemann Sums. Also, I had to get used to the university style questions as they require more thought than high school questions. Study Avery's long note documents as the exam questions are very similar to that.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Honestly, Avery is one of the smartest professors I have seen in HKUST but being completely honest, he can't teach. He says "uhhh" half the time and goes about solving questions in a way which I am not used to. Don't worry if you don't understand his methodology. There are much easier ways to do the questions. Alternatively, you can turn to YouTubers such as Khan Academy or PatrickJMT who are able to teach you the content in a brief and concise manner. But as aforementioned, his note documents are the key to success in his class. Do make sure you can do every question.

However, do go for Phyllis's tutorials. She is one of the best TA's in the math department and her notes are so jeng. She has everything one must know for the topic and all sorts of difficulty of questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading was pretty decent. There were two grading schemes.

Scheme 1:
15% Webwork (Homework) + 30% Mid-term + 55% Final Exam

or

Scheme 2:
15% Webwork + 85% Final Exam (for those who could not do the midterm due to the social unrest and special situation)

My grades:
100/100 for Webwork (Unlimited Attempts)
38/50 for Mid-Term (Mean was 26.7 and SD was around 11)
15/15 for Final Exam (Mean was 8.67)
Overall: 92.8% (A+)
*The overall mean was like 61.6 with an SD of 20.5
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was honestly not that heavy. I just used to do briefly look over the content since I knew the majority of it and did some practise questions to solidify my knowledge. However, if you have no background to calculus, the concept did take me a while to understand in high school so don't be afraid if you don't understand it right away.

reviews.author: Wolfheart
reviews.title: This course is an injustice
reviews.comment_content:
Personally, I studied Maths SL in IB. Most of the students in the course studied DSE and may have had a different experience than I had.

The content up to the midterms consisted of limits and basic knowledge on derivatives. The difficulty was okay. All content on derivatives was covered in IB, and I had to learn about limits, mostly through Khan Academy, practicing past papers, and asking my peers.

Finals suddenly got a lot more difficult and required studying to catch up, especially with the pace of how frequently Webworks were released. This is also where the part on word problems are introduced, and personally, in my opinion, those types of questions just required a degree of creativity to answer.

Warning: This course will truly foster your HATRED for maths in the future. The effort required for most people is disproportionate to the outcome of this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Avery tries to be funny in his class, but he ends up acting silly. Despite his jolly personality during class, do not be deceived by how sadistic he is for the midterm and final exam of this course. People complain about his English and some may complain about his heavy accent, but given that this is a math course, I believe that his message is usually clear. His e-mails are written like a kindergartener though, but they inspire fear in you when you receive it as he often includes the mean and SD of the relevant assessment in the e-mail.

Lectures are generally useless and skippable. There is a decent chance that you may doze off or fall asleep. Watching Khan Academy or videos from similar people would be more helpful in understanding contents of the course. Practicing solving and doing homework has actually taught me more than attending class as well.

I didn't utilise the help of the T.A., Walter, but he seems to be friendly in tutorials. I also did not ask for help from the Math Support Centre because consulting them through an online environment would've been unnecessarily difficult, so I cannot comment on my experiences with the two parties.
reviews.comment_grading:
For this semester, the course has two grading schemes:
Scheme 1 - 15% Webwork, 30% midterm, 55% finals; or
Scheme 2 - 15% Webwork, 85% finals

Avery then chooses the higher grade produced by the two schemes. I'm not sure if the course used absolute grading like its sibling course, MATH 1013, but since the SD and mean of the midterm and final grades were given, it was probably curved.

Now, for the gravely unjust grading system:
15% Webwork: 93.33% (mean: 93.8%; I forgot to submit on one week)

55% Final: 11/15 (mean: 7.1 based on Canvas)
30% Midterm: 40/50 (mean: 24.2, SD: 11.9)
or
85% Final: 11/15 (mean: 7.1 based on Canvas)

Final Grade: 78.33% (mean: 61.6, SD: 20.5) under Scheme 1
B+

Roughly 0.75SD above for a B+. I have a friend who scored exactly 1SD above and also received a B+.

I can't imagine what the letter grade for mean or below mean is. To my knowledge, 1 SD above should receive an A-.

Furthermore, the grading of scheme 2 was absolutely illogical and stupid. This fall-term arrangement for finals had 12 multiple-choice questions overall -- 10 questions worth one point and 2 questions worth 2 points. Each student had two attempts to do the exam on Canvas. Let me just rant about how I did the computation and losing just one point was equivalent to a 5.x% decrease in the final grade.

The printed final examination (based on the sample final) includes questions on a broader range of topics and is more indicative of one's level of understanding of the course.

Combining the preposterous and overwhelming weight of 85%, along with the disappointing letter grade, you get MATH 1012.
reviews.comment_workload:
There is Math homework on the Webwork platform that is released weekly and accounts for 15% of the final grade. Make sure to do the homework and try to score 100%. Set up a weekly reminder if you have to. If there's a question you've been stuck on, don't be afraid to search for the answer on Google or use software like Wolfram Alpha. It's not worth it to end up forgetting about the homework entirely.

As for the midterm and final, Math is all about practice. The lecture notes generally provide a complete overview of what you need to know. It isn't enough though, and you should definitely practice on past papers to get a feel of the exam structure and adequate pacing.

MATH 1012 barely has any past papers. Throughout the course, students were provided only the 2015 version of the midterm and finals. In contrast, you should practice on MATH 1013 past papers. The syllabus is 90% similar to MATH 1012, with topics like linear approximation and Newton's Iteration Formula being two of the concepts excluded from the MATH 1012 syllabus. However, questions in MATH 1013 are harder, so if you are able answer them, MATH 1012 will suddenly feel easier. In addition, MATH 1013 has more sets available online with dates from 2012-2016, although not all of the exams have solution sets available to them.

As for the midterm of this course, it was very similar to the sample MATH 1012 midterm provided to us. The breakdown of the questions by topic were almost the same -- long questions included a topic on limits, derivatives, and graphing. Multiple choice also contained questions that only had their values changed.

reviews.author: jimmy5678998
reviews.title: You can learn nothing except hating calculus in this course
reviews.comment_content:
This is an introductory course in one-variable calculus, the first in the Calculus I and II sequence, designed for students that have not taken HKDSE Mathematics Extended Module M1 or M2. Topics include functions and their limits, continuity, derivatives and rules of differentiation, applications of derivatives, and basic integral calculus.

Yes, correct, but it is not just basic in my opinion. As a student that never have been tapped in calculus, it is already very hard and advanced. (Moreover, I am weak at maths. :( )

It is fairly acceptable before midterm, which only included some basic differentiation and trigonometric identities, (but double angle formulas are as hard as hell for me.) But once you reach the final exam, it is another stuff. The preparation for the final exam took me at least 2 whole weeks to handle well with integration by doing the exercises given by tutorial. And when I tried to do the final exam past paper, I have no idea on how to do the first long question at all! The final exam past paper given is just ridiculously hard and not able to do the long question section. Although the final exam is an open-notes, full multiple-choice question paper due to the epidemic and the difficulty is decreased, it is still challenging for a newcomer to calculus.

The lectures teach you basic theory on calculus with simple examples. While the tutorials give you more moderate exercises. So that you can earn some confidences from them. When the exams arrive, they give you questions with 100% different from what you have done before, so that you have no idea on how to solve them, crash your confidences that you have built before, and your grade is broken.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Mr Lam is good at teaching and I am fortunate to be taught by him. It is easy to understand the theory with his explanations.  He will solve some webwork questions in class and it is nice. The only problem is the questions taught in class are too easy compared to exam level. And you will find a hard time if you are studying for final exam with just his notes.

Mr Chan's tutorial notes are useful and help me to overcome a lot of basic problems compared to other tutors notes that I have done. Still, the question types are not rich enough on dealing with the exams.

My pals keep complaining about Avery's teaching to me, but I haven't been taught by him, so it is not good for me to comment. Maybe you can try his teaching yourself(or watching other comments are already enough). :)

It is good to point out that I only attended for the first 3 tutorials, then I had skipped all of them, as I feel like the difference is not big if you have finished all the exercises in notes.  While I attended the first 7 lectures because I feel okay and not waste my time. But for the remaining 13 lectures(not included with 7 video lectures after November), I think I have things more meaningful(like playing and studying mahjong) rather than attending them.

TL:DR, don't waste time on things you don't interest in and can't improve your result significantly. JUST SKIPPED THEM ALL ARE STILL FINE FOR YOUR EXAM(as you still don't do well on the exam).
reviews.comment_grading:
if you are good at maths, the course is fine for you. I believe getting A is not that hard for geniuses. Even so, paying more efforts to ensure you to get high enough marks.

If you are bad at maths like me(DSE math level 3~4), you better to be prepared to get C or B- even you did tons of exercises included sources from the internet, you just don't have enough talent to overcome the problem sometimes.

Find some pals that you can work with and good at maths would help you a lot, start studying at least before 2 weeks the exam, and struggle with those who are not good at so you feel less painful when you don't know how to do the maths. B range can be reached if you are determined, but don't think of A, it is just fate if you can't get the thing you hope for.

my score:
Midterm:35/50 (mean: 25.45)
Final: 12/15 (mean: 7.8)
webwork:100% done with 100% mark
I believe I get a B grade. Nevertheless, the grading of this course is shit.
(update: B+ turns out,no A- so sad)

weighing methods:
Method 1:15%(webwork) + 30%(midterm) + 55%(final)
Method 2:15%(webwork) + 85%(final)
reviews.comment_workload:
9 hard webworks
1 challenging and losing-confidence midterm
1 super hard, non-human to do (except this seminar) final exam
That's it.

Not many works to do, except working, studying, revising for final exam two whole weeks without playing any games(including mahjong!!).

Webworks should be finished all and get full marks as you have unlimited attempts, otherwise you will have a hard time on the exams(the question type are some kind of similar and worth to do).
But I think it's fine for those who did well at maths, as they have a clear mind on how to answer them so they do not need to do a lot of works to enhance themselves, I believe. (No offense)

The past paper of 2015 final exam is attached for reference. I think it is extremely hard on long-question section. You can try to do it and decided whether you shall work more or less for better grading.

reviews.author: maria.13
reviews.title: Lousy course for non-calculus background
reviews.comment_content:
The material is equivalent to the calculus in IB Math SL + HL + HL Calculus Option combined, so if a student has never seen calculus before, it will be quite difficult to keep up with the course.
The content seems very uncoordinated across the lecture, tutorial, homework, and exams. The lecture and tutorial go over the same content at different times which makes it highly confusing. Furthermore, the questions in the tutorial, homework, and exams are different in type and difficulty level making it hard to deduce the exam content.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Absolutely terrible. The lectures are boring and hard to follow (you can see the diminishing number of students attending the lectures over the weeks). The professor spends more time going over confusing proofs rather than explaining the content.
The tutorial isn't any better. Although the tutorial goes over more of the practice question, their difficult level is no where near the difficultly of the exam questions.
I found IB textbooks more useful than any of the lectures or tutorials.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework: 15%
Midterm: 35%
Final: 50%
The curve surprisingly saved me. My midterm grade was much better than my final grade, although still not satisfactory. The problem is, is that the grader may not grant you points if your methodology does not match the one in the mark scheme, which can significantly impact your overall score.
reviews.comment_workload: If you have a calculus background, at first it will seem like there's nothing much to do, but the content gradually gets more difficult so you will probably have to study more towards the end of the course. The homework does not take too long, although some questions can be quite puzzling (make sure to do all the homework as it is counted in your final grade). However, if you do not have a calculus background, you will probably have a lot of studying and catching up to do.

reviews.author: Sola
reviews.comment_content:
Function
Differentiation
Integration
reviews.comment_teaching:
The lecture is about the theory, proof of differentiation and integration. For the exam, you only know how to do the questions so many people skipped the lecture.

For the tutorial, I think is very useful as the tutors will only talk about the questions and do it with you.

Therefore, I would say you can skip the lecture but you should not skip the tutorial classes.
reviews.comment_grading:
15% Homework, 30% Midterm Exam, 55% Final Exam
HW: It is easy for you to get full marks for webwork as you can attempt for unlimited times.

Midterm: Not hard, the mean was  about 26/50, my score was 43/50

Final: Hard for students who have never studied M1 or M2, I am ok in differentiation but bad at integration. Therefore, I got 26/60, the mean was about 21/60.

At last, I got a B so I would say the grading is fair.
reviews.comment_workload: There are only 10 sets of webwork exercise.

reviews.author: drrusti
reviews.title: Bearable
reviews.comment_content:
The content of this course includes the first five chapters of James Stewart's 'Calculus Early Transcendentals, 7th Edition' which is comprised of the following:

Chapter 1: Functions and Models
Chapter 2: Limits and Derivatives
Chapter 3: Differentiation Rules
Chapter 4: Applications of Differentiation
Chapter 5: Integrals

As an IB SL Math student it was rather challenging to learn some of the theory presented. However, even with only an SL math understanding, the concepts of this course can definitely be tackled with hard work and study of the textbook.

Yet even if you do this, the questions on the exams are much harder than most you would have practised. To add onto that, Professor Avery likes to trick his students. It seems that the only way to get A+ is to work from day 1 and truly have a clear understanding of the content.  

I STRONGLY SUGGEST FINDING THE TEXTBOOK FOR SELF-STUDY
reviews.comment_teaching:
Avery's teaching is pretty tough to keep up with. It is very hard to actually learn from his lectures as he skips a lot of steps, making it very confusing for people who aren't well versed in maths.

The most redeeming part of the teaching component in this course is the tutorials. I had Ms. Phyllis Liang as my tutor and she was more than happy to help. Otherwise, I found myself visiting the MSC a lot.

reviews.author: shaolinmonk
reviews.title: An Adventure into the mind of Avery Ching
reviews.comment_content: I feel the content packs a lot into 1 semester. Limits, differentiation and integration taught from 0. I feel for those which do not have a math background like me.
reviews.comment_teaching: It goes without saying that Avery Ching is very passionate about maths, however, I feel he is a very difficult instructor. His Uhhhh and So, what next have become memes. He also writes a lot of redundant notes which ends up becoming quite useless when studying. Be prepared to fall asleep more than once during his lectures. However, he has been kind enough to offer 5-minute breaks and occasionally lets us leave early. He is also very open to answering any questions you have.
reviews.comment_grading: Math grading is known to be unforgiving. Full marks for homework, way above mean for both midterm and final. Got a B.
reviews.comment_workload: Be prepared to devote hours per day trying the infamous webwork. It is not entirely difficult, but the most difficult questions could take 2 hours per question. I felt I was entirely self-studying this course. I had to study for close to 100 hours for both midterm and final.

reviews.author: MaxH
reviews.title: Good course to equip you with fundamental calculus knowledge
reviews.comment_content:
Easy calculus(differentiation and integration) and not so difficult.
1 Number, inequalities and absolutes (Appendix A), basic functions and graphs,
composite functions (1.1, 1.2, 1.3)
2 Exponential functions (1.5), trigonometric functions (Appendix D), inverse functions,
logarithmic functions, inverse trigonometric functions (1.6)
3 Tangent and velocity (2.1), the limit of a function, limit laws (2.2, 2.3)
4 Continuity (2.5), limits at infinity and horizontal asymptotes (2.6), derivatives and
rates of change (2.7)
5 Basic derivatives (2.8, 3.1), product and quotient rules (3.2), derivatives of
trigonometric functions (3.3)
6 Chain rule (3.4), implicit differentiation, derivatives of inverse trigonometric
functions and logarithmic functions (3.5, 3.6)
7 Rates of change problems (3.7, 3.8), related rates (3.9)
8 Maximum and minimum values (4.1)
9 Derivatives and graphs (4.3), Lâ€™HÃ´pitalâ€™s rule (4.4)
10 Curve sketching (4.5, 4.6), optimization problems (4.7)
11 Antiderivatives (4.9), areas (5.1)
12 Definite integrals (5.2), the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus (5.3)
13 Indefinite integrals and net change (5.4), the substitution rule. (5.5)
reviews.comment_teaching: Normal, I think it is more or less the same. Professors just keep proofing formula during the lessons and work a few examples. You can skip the lectures and just attend the tutorials since TA would teach you how to solve the problems effectively and much more useful
reviews.comment_grading:
15% by homework and classwork
30% by midterm exam
55% by final exam
class mean for midterm is 28/50, final mean is 25/60
I get 47/50 in midterm and 54/60 in final . Overall:91/100
Finally, i get an A+ Grade. Put some effort and you can easily get A range
reviews.comment_workload: acceptable, around 10 homework in webwork and around 1 per week, one midterm and one final exam.

reviews.author: goat123
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1 Review of the concepts of functions and graphs.  
Week 2 Elementary functions.  
Week 3 Tangent and velocity; the limit of  a function and limit laws.  
Week 4 Continuity; limit at infinity; limit definition of derivative and rates of change.
Week 5 Derivatives of basic functions; differentiation rules.  
Week 6 Chain rule and implicit differentiation.  
Week 7 Rates and related rates.  
Week 8 Maximum and minimum values.  
Week 9 Derivatives and the shape of a graph; L'Hopital's Rule.  
Week 10 Curve sketching; optimization problems.  
Week 11 Antiderivatives; areas and distance travelled.  
Week 12 Definite integrals; Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.  
Week 13 Net change; substitution rule.

Most of the course were covered by HL maths.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lectures tend to focus on theories as opposed to solving questions. I suggest attending all tutorial lessons as they provide useful resources and teach you how to answer exam style questions.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading was reasonable. If you manage to complete all the Webworks you should be able to pass. Study well for the midterm as it was easier to score in this exam compared to the final.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is pretty much optional with exception to the compulsory webwork assignments which are provided every week via Webwork. I suggest going to the maths support centre if you don't know how to answer certain questions. If you want a good grade I suggest that you complete all the tutorial resources provided to you.

reviews.title: struggled so hard

6 Chain rule (3.4), implicit differentiation, derivatives of inverse trigonometric functions and logarithmic functions (3.5, 3.6)

reviews.comment_teaching: It was alright for the basics at first but then I found myself difficult to follow up for the second half of semester. Tutorials notes are quite useful!
reviews.comment_grading:
Full mark for webwork is a must!!
Final is a lot harder so do your best in the midterm!
15% Webwork
30% Midterm Exam
55% Final Exam
reviews.comment_workload: Not much. Only questions from webwork every week, although I always get stuck on one or two questions....

reviews.author: H.Y
reviews.comment_content:
Content:
Functions
Limits
Derivatives
Optimization
Integration

Tutorial notes are very clear and understandable
reviews.comment_teaching: I only attend the first lecture, it is quite boring, attend the tutorial is more helpful. If you didn't learn calculus at all, just attend the tutorial is fine. If you have learned before, then you don't need to attend any of them.
reviews.comment_grading:
grading is pretty well, midterm and final are both easy

Midterm 35%  
Webworks 15%
Final 50%
I got 50/50 in the midterm, full in all webwork, and 56/60 in final, got A+
reviews.comment_workload: only easy webwork, like ten easy questions per week

reviews.author: halo123
reviews.comment_content:
This course is for those who didn't take M1 or M2 in secondary school.
Week 1 Review of the concepts of functions and graphs.  
Week 2 Elementary functions.  
Week 3 Tangent and velocity; the limit of  a function and limit laws.
Week 4 Continuity; limit at infinity; limit definition of derivative and rates of change.  
Week 5 Derivatives of basic functions; differentiation rules.
Week 6 Chain rule and implicit differentiation.
Week 7 Rates and related rates.  
Week 8 Mean Value Theorem. Maximum and minimum values.
Week 9 Derivatives and the shape of a graph; L'Hopital's Rule.  
Week 10 Curve sketching; optimization problems.  
Week 11 Antiderivatives; areas and distance travelled.  
Week 12 Definite integrals; Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.
Week 13 Net change; substitution rule.
The course requires student to learn a tons of content in such a short period of time. You have to learn 3 years with of use math in 3 months. Hell for non-math lovers. Worst course in the semester. I enjoyed nothing in the course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
In lectures, lecturer prove math theory instead of teaching you how to apply the stuffs you have learnt so it's kind of useless if you are not interested in math. In tutorial the tutors would teach you different math problems so be sure to attend the tutorials.
However, it is really hard to understand the content .
reviews.comment_grading: There's a huge gap between the lesson materials and exams. The questions in exams are way more difficult than the questions in tutorials/webwork.
reviews.comment_workload: Webwork every week. You have to lots of exercise and still cannot solve the problems in the exam.

reviews.author: æ’éª¨
reviews.title: I don't like this
reviews.comment_content:
Basic Calculus
Yes, the things they teach are basic enough, but as always the exams are set ridiculously hard. What do you even expect from a math course?
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor has heart I guess, but his accent really is unintelligible, so can't understand anything. I only attended 3 lectures total, but you may as well skip them since you can't understand anything anyways. The tutorials on the other hand are useful, make good use of them.
reviews.comment_grading: Curve grading, nothing much to say. Got 70% overall (1 SD above mean) and got a B for your reference
reviews.comment_workload: Webwork. Thats all. Wolfram Alpha and Symbolab will help you immensly

reviews.author: Jasa
reviews.title: Bad teacher but good grade
reviews.comment_content:
He cutted quite a lot syllabus, like concave up not taught, but he likes to digress, ironic.

His lecture note is not understandable.
In fact, his TA's tutorial note is very very clear.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I give a C, which is A for tutorial, E for lecture.

I quitted his lecture after September.
I only attend tutorial, Phyllips, who is very very  good at teaching.

For English, Avery thought he speaks well and fun, in fact it was not.

For word, his real teaching and trash is 1:1. He spoke many trash and Errr, Arrrrr all the time, which is confusing.
reviews.comment_grading:
Best grading. Not absolute grading but curve grading.

Midterm: 80/100
Final: 87/100
Overall 87 --> A

It is easy to get A as there are many newbies in this class. And 87 should be a A- in 1013 with absolute grading.

The paper is fair. Most MC are same with 1013 as I checked with my frd, but long Qs are a lot easier.
reviews.comment_workload:
Easy Webwork.

In case if u find it difficult, just find your 1013 frd, the questions are exact7ly the same.
Moreover, our deadline are later than 1013, so you may find your 1013 frd for the ans directly.

reviews.author: WilliamLeung
reviews.title: calculus IA
reviews.comment_content:
-Review of the concepts of functions and graphs
-Elementary functions
-Tangent and velocity; the limit of a function and limit laws
-Continuity; limit at infinity; limit definition of derivative and rates of change
-Derivatives of basic functions; differentiation rules
-Chain rule and implicit differentiation
-Rates and related rates
-Maximum and minimum values
-Derivatives and the shape of a graph; L'Hopital's Rule
-Curve sketching; optimization problems
-Antiderivatives; areas and distance traveled
-Definite integrals; Fundamental Theorem of Calculus

reviews.comment_teaching:
He is a very nice tutor

Attend the tutorials session (highly recommended)
the tutors are nice and they focus on problem-solving skills and techniques that are necessary for exams

You can skip lectures, but sometimes, lectures explain the logic and provide you the proof of theorems which you may need for your exams and webwork assignments.

You can also go to the math support center for any troubles you encounter when finishing the assignment. ( you are allowed to resubmit the answers unlimited time, so don't be afraid of having the wrong answers in the firsplace
reviews.comment_grading:
35% mid-term
15% webworks
50% final
reviews.comment_workload:
9 homework assignments
1 mid-term exam
1 final exam

reviews.author: lhtam
reviews.title: Require much effort to pass this course
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1 Review of the concepts of functions and graphs.  (1.2-1.3; Appendix A.)
Week 2 Elementary functions.  (1.5-1.6; Appendix B-D.)
Week 3 Tangent and velocity; the limit of  a function and limit laws.  (2.1-2.3.)
Week 4 Continuity; limit at infinity; limit definition of derivative and rates of change.  (2.5-2.7.)
Week 5 Derivatives of basic functions; differentiation rules.  (2.8, 3.1-3.3.)
Week 6 Chain rule and implicit differentiation.  (2.8, 3.1-3.3.)
Week 7 Rates and related rates.  (3.7-3.9.)
Week 8 Maximum and minimum values.  (3.10, 4.1.)
Week 9 Derivatives and the shape of a graph; L'Hopital's Rule.  (4.3-4.4.)
Week 10 Curve sketching; optimization problems.  (4.5-4.7.)
Week 11 Antiderivatives; areas and distance travelled.  (4.9, 5.1.)
Week 12 Definite integrals; Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.  (5.2-5.3.)
Week 13 Net change; substitution rule.  (5.4-5.5.)

Content is tough for ppl who did not study M1/2 before. Expected that you can't catch up after the differentiation part as they rushed over the application of differentiation and integration part due to tight teaching schedule.
reviews.comment_teaching:
There are two 1.5 hrs lecture per week held by Dr. Wei, mainly focus on proofing the theory, which I found useless in order to pass the exams. Yet his teaching is way better than Avery, his accent is acceptable.

However, the big tutorial (50mins) and small tutorial (50mins) held by Kenneth Ng (TA) per week are very useful as he mainly focus on how to solve the problem. He will explain everything clearly and definitely feel his passion in teaching! Quite unfortunate that he resigned this semester as he applied research position :(

All in all, you could skip all the lectures but attending tutorial is HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.
reviews.comment_grading:
WebWork (9 homework in total) 15%
Mid-term Exam (1hr 30mins) 30%
Final Exam (3hrs) 55%

Try to complete ALL homework, it saves you to pass this course.
Mid-term is relatively easy this year but the final blown my mind which I cant even calculate one question.

So here's my result:
WebWork (15%) - 15/15, above mean
Mid-term Exam (30%), mean ~27/50, got 24/50, below mean
Final Exam (55%), mean ~22/60, got 24/60, above mean
Overall: 51.4%, got C+

As long as you have 30% you will pass this course.
reviews.comment_workload: I'm a retaker of this course which I failed in 17/18 Fall semester. I failed last year because I can't catch up the content and the TA cant help as they are not really patient and teach well. So I spent the whole summer to understand and drilling the course content (so actually I spent 6 months to prep this course!). You definitely need others help because lecturer and TA are not enough. For ppl who take this course for the first time, you better pay extra effort. For maths noob (like me), you will know the pain :(

reviews.author: Andy HK
reviews.title: won't understand without a close friend or tutor to teach you
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1 Review of the concepts of functions and graphs.  (1.2-1.3; Appendix A.)
Week 2 Elementary functions.  (1.5-1.6; Appendix B-D.)
Week 3 Tangent and velocity; the limit of  a function and limit laws.  (2.1-2.3.)
Week 4 Continuity; limit at infinity; limit definition of derivative and rates of change.  (2.5-2.7.)
Week 5 Derivatives of basic functions; differentiation rules.  (2.8, 3.1-3.3.)
Week 6 Chain rule and implicit differentiation.  (2.8, 3.1-3.3.)
Week 7 Rates and related rates.  (3.7-3.9.)
Week 8 Maximum and minimum values.  (3.10, 4.1.)
Week 9 Derivatives and the shape of a graph; L'Hopital's Rule.  (4.3-4.4.)
Week 10 Curve sketching; optimization problems.  (4.5-4.7.)
Week 11 Antiderivatives; areas and distance travelled.  (4.9, 5.1.)
Week 12 Definite integrals; Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.  (5.2-5.3.)
Week 13 Net change; substitution rule.  (5.4-5.5.)
reviews.comment_teaching:
I enrolled in the class taught by Wang Erxiao but I completely could not understand what he said and attending his lecture was useless. But he would review the mid-term and final exam past paper 2-3 lessons just before the exam, which was an advantage because the course coordinator did not do that, so it is suggested to attend these lectures even if you skip regular lecture.
I attended Avery Ching's lecture from time to time because I would like to try the coordinator's lecture.  I failed to understand the content as well but I could still get the meaning sometimes, and at least learn something. Avery Ching did not provide lecture ppt and all the notes were in hand-written format during the lesson.
One advantage of Wang ErXiao was that his lecture notes were well-organized, so I could self-study by reading his lecture notes, and learn from the example.
reviews.comment_grading:
WeBWorK Online Homework: 15% (Mean is 90%)
Midterm Exam : 30% (Mean is 30/50)
Final Exam: 55% (Mean is 25.85/60)
I got 35/50 in mid-term exam, 15% for webwork, final exam score is not released. I got B+ finally.
I would like to share my story here. Normally, all students taking this course are year 1 but I took this course in year3 the first time because of some reasons. I was afraid of this course since the first semester in year1 until I got a unexpected grade finally. The content was definitely terrible and unacceptable. I have a twin brother studying at UST as well, who got B+ in this subject too. He has studied M2 in high school but dropped it in form 5. He said math1012 content required 2 years to be taught in secondary school. But we need to learn both form4 and form5 knowledges within 3 months.
If it had not been for my twin brother who taught me the math1012 content in advance, during the winter break and summer holiday in year1 and year2, I must not be able to pass this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
The webwork exercises were extremely difficult and time-consuming. Many of the exercises were done by my brother. I also went to math support center to ask for some questions. But some of the tutors in math support center were a little bit arrogant and inapproachable. The attitude of one tutor who is a bit old was extraordinarily poor. When i was talking to another tutor who taught the tutorial of my session, the old tutor suddenly joined the conversation and his tone and content seemed like punishing me. Fortunately, there was a student helper who taught me patiently every time. I remember he needed to be on duty for 2 hours that day, he spended 2 hours to answer my questions and i understood the questions of the past paper completely. Otherwise, i would not ace the final exam. I was exceedingly grateful for his help but I donâ€™t know how to contact him and thank for him, which is a pity.
A suggestion for you is that for a few sets of exercises concerning the calculation of differentiation, limit and integration, you can surf the internet and type differentiation calculator, limit calculator and integration calculator to help you get the answer if you don't know how to do or have no time.

reviews.comment_content: Most of the content is what we learn in IB SL, but we are not allowed  to use GDCs in the exam. Need to attend the tutorials at least to understand how to solve certain kinds of Qs.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor's accent is hard to understand. Found that tutorials do help a lot, as they are better in explaining concepts, giving us practices, handouts etc.
reviews.comment_grading: I am not sure yet, as I haven't received my grade yet. Found finals harder than the midterm exam.
reviews.comment_workload: HW almost every week, sometimes twice a week. Personally, found them really annoying but doing them properly could help you prepare for the exams.

reviews.author: Grace Tang
reviews.title: A nightmare
reviews.comment_content: Algebras that might have taught in DSE M2. Since this course is designed for those who didn't take any algebras in their secondary level. You're like learning a 3 years DSE algebras curriculum within 3 months. If you are not good at maths, you'll find this course extremely tough. But you can borrow your friends' DSE textbook so that it can give you a better understanding.
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructor tries to prove the theory step by step. Though it seems to be clear, but I still don't get it. The tutorials are good, since you can ask questions.
reviews.comment_grading: Quite fair. I got below mean for more than 1 SD in midterm and slightly below mean in the final. And you can always have webwork to help pull up your grade (you can do thousands of times to make sure the answers are correct). And i got a C. I think it is acceptable
reviews.comment_workload: Fair. You need to webwork base on each chapter. Though the questions are quite hard if you don't get the concept. But you may google it or go to maths support center to ask

it was the worst lesson. even though it is the beginner course but it was super hard for students who didn't m1 m2 to understand

just do all tutorial notes before the exam and you will have at least a D

15% Webwork
35% midterm
50% final

The exams place somewhat high weighting on the MC section, which screwed me over.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload pretty much depends on your understanding of what is being taught. If you understand most of it then the workload won't be that much.

There are 10 Webwork homeworks in total. Webwork is very difficult for me, I often had to go to the Math Support Center for help, but even then I still wouldn't really understand.

reviews.author: KST
reviews.title: Not very interesting.
reviews.comment_content:
The content is not easy.
Some basic knowledge of Calculus, like derivatives,chain rules,functions.

Sometime I may not be able to catch up or understand the lecture. So, for me,self-practice and self-learning is needed.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor always proof the theories but not teaching you how to solve and apply it. But it is still better to attend the lectures and get to know the topics.

Every lecture, professor will revise what he taught in the previous one. That's quite useful.

The tutorial is quite practical which teach you how to solve the questions but won't help you much if you don't understand the theories.
reviews.comment_grading: Not graded yet.
reviews.comment_workload:
One WebWork assignment weekly.
Nothing else.

reviews.author: Ansonrain
reviews.comment_content:
Week Topics
1 Number, inequalities and absolutes (Appendix A), basic functions and graphs,
composite functions (1.1, 1.2, 1.3)
2 Exponential functions (1.5), trigonometric functions (Appendix D), inverse functions,
logarithmic functions, inverse trigonometric functions (1.6)
3 Tangent and velocity (2.1), the limit of a function, limit laws (2.2, 2.3)
4 Continuity (2.5), limits at infinity and horizontal asymptotes (2.6), derivatives and
rates of change (2.7)
5 Basic derivatives (2.8, 3.1), product and quotient rules (3.2), derivatives of
trigonometric functions (3.3)
6 Chain rule (3.4), implicit differentiation, derivatives of inverse trigonometric
functions and logarithmic functions (3.5, 3.6)
7 Rates of change problems (3.7, 3.8), related rates (3.9)
8 Maximum and minimum values (4.1)
9 Derivatives and graphs (4.3), Lâ€™HÃ´pitalâ€™s rule (4.4)
10 Curve sketching (4.5, 4.6), optimization problems (4.7)
11 Antiderivatives (4.9), areas (5.1)
12 Definite integrals (5.2), the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus (5.3)
13 Indefinite integrals and net change (5.4), the substitution rule. (5.5)
reviews.comment_teaching: It is quite lots of things to learn since I don't have M2 background. So it's not easy for me to catch up with his teaching in every lecture. The worse thing is that his teaching flow is fast. When you get stuck in some maths terms, u will suck.  Besides, the TA for T3 shows a remarkable maths background but his teaching may have to be improved in the way he delivers knowledge.
reviews.comment_grading: At this moment, I have not attended the mid-term and final exam, so it's hard to say it.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload seems moderate to me as I am self-motivated. I always finish the web works after it published.

reviews.author: Leung Yui Chit
reviews.title: Very useful
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1 Review of the concepts of functions and graphs.  (1.2-1.3; Appendix A.)
Week 2 Elementary functions.  (1.5-1.6; Appendix B-D.)
Week 3 Tangent and velocity; the limit of  a function and limit laws.  (2.1-2.3.)
Week 4 Continuity; limit at infinity; limit definition of derivative and rates of change.  (2.5-2.7.)
Week 5 Derivatives of basic functions; differentiation rules.  (2.8, 3.1-3.3.)
Week 6 Chain rule and implicit differentiation.  (2.8, 3.1-3.3.)
Week 7 Rates and related rates.  (3.7-3.9.)
Week 8 Mean Value Theorem. Maximum and minimum values.  (3.10, 4.1.)
Week 9 Derivatives and the shape of a graph; L'Hopital's Rule.  (4.3-4.4.)
Week 10 Curve sketching; optimization problems.  (4.5-4.7.)
Week 11 Antiderivatives; areas and distance traveled.  (4.9, 5.1.)
Week 12 Definite integrals; Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.  (5.2-5.3.)
Week 13 Net change; substitution rule.  (5.4-5.5.)

The content is adequate to explain fundamentals of calculus, but for better coverage, I recommend to learn the content from MIT OCW.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor is extremely bad at explaining, heavy accent, makes easy concepts very complicated, it may be quite intimidating for students as he said many 'ah, er, la'.
reviews.comment_grading:
Had a bit of M2 background. (dropped after learning integration)
Did not do much exercise.
Started revising for mid term 3 days before, and final.4-5 days.

midterm above 1.3 SD
final (mean changes from year to year) : unknown mean and SD

My grade: A-
reviews.comment_workload: Quite heavy workload. The content would get harder over the course, hence constant effort are needed. TA gives additional practice problems, if you choose to do these, then the workload is extremely high.

reviews.author: PakHo
reviews.title: Not that bad
reviews.comment_content: For those who haven't study m1 m2 is super difficult and u miay need to ask others for help
reviews.comment_teaching: Boring for lecture, just keep proving theories but never teach u single question while the ta seldom tell you how to solve the question outside curriculum
reviews.comment_grading: Ok grading ,haven't attend in mid-term and still passed for those people who want to wash grade can just go to take this course
reviews.comment_workload: homework every week and many of them is very difficult but still can handle with pass paper

reviews.author: min2124745
reviews.comment_content:
functions and graphs.  
velocity and tangent
Derivatives, Optimization, Integration.
reviews.comment_teaching: quite boring and lecturer sometimes make things more unclear even though it was the content which was quite familiar to me.
reviews.comment_grading: grading is quite specific. Mean will end you up with C. Harsh grading for an 'intro' to calculus, make sure you do well in midterm. Final is harder to score in so get a better mark in midterm.
reviews.comment_workload: every week there is a webwork due to end of that week along with quiz. workload is quite much but still ok compared to other courses

reviews.author: CyrusLung
reviews.title: Math 1012
reviews.comment_content: Teaching is bad, Grading is bad. If you are good at mathematics or have your M1/M2 dropped in secondary school time. It may be easier for you to catch up with the course.
reviews.comment_teaching: bullshit teaching, you can skip all the lectures, but remember not to skip the tutorial.
reviews.comment_grading: Bad. All assignment get full mark, mid-term below one sd, final higher than one sd, still get a C+.
reviews.comment_workload: Simply just have some web work to do, together with one mid-term and one final, workload is quite light. And no attendance need to be taken.

reviews.author: PTMS
reviews.title: Bad teaching with fair grading
reviews.comment_content:
Simple calculus intro
limit
differentiation
integration
part  of m1 and m2 syllabus but luckily people with passing m1 or m2 will study in 1013, so 1012 only the ones with no calculus background.
reviews.comment_teaching:
worst thing ever.
Avery is teaching the proof of the differentiation and integration, and all his does is just simply talking boring and irrelevant things about the course. He only teaches a few calculation which is not helpful for the midterm and exam....
However, the TA Zeta gives off a ton of exercise and he will spend 1 lecture and tutorial per week to teach about the calculation, which makes u at least have some exercise to prepare for the midterm and Exam, which is quite good tbh...
reviews.comment_grading:
From what I've heard, he set a passing mark for this score, only the one with or above passing mark will be involve into the curve, which makes him seems bad grade.
For me
midterm = mean (20~22/50)
exam = below mean 1 s.d.
final grade C
is ok grading if u managed to score with the passing mark.
But it is very hard for many people to get the passing mark as his teaching is like shit while his mt and exam is very difficult.
reviews.comment_workload:
It depends.
every week u are required to do webwork and the answer can be found on google, which is alright...
but u really need to prepare a lot for the midterm and exam

Week 1 Review of the concepts of functions and graphs.  
Week 2 Elementary functions.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Boring teaching.
Teaching theories but not calculations.

Don't choose his section if you have choice or you will regret.

You could just skip the lessons and work on the problems yourself at home, just go to MSC to ask for help when you need some. Attending lectures for this course is completely useless and time wasting.
reviews.comment_grading:
15% Webwork
35% Mid-term exam
50% Final exam

Difficult to get good grade if you didn't have any calculus background like me.
Easy to get good grade if you do.

If you get an F, unfortunately, don't hesitate to retake during winter semester, although the workload will be much higher ( 3 lectures per week and 4 hours each, much easier to get a better grade)
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite heavy, it's a 4 cred course after all, around 1 webwork per week.

But if you are only trying to complete the things and get the 15%, just seek for help from yahoo answers / symbolab, would only take you less than 1 hour for each webwork.
