reviews.author: nightkirin
reviews.comment_content: four main topic function, limit, depreciation and basic integration. it's very basic if you have study M2 before in hkdse . basically, you already finished 90% of the syllabus.However, if you haven't, This is a really hard time for us
reviews.comment_teaching: avery is a poor speaker he just copies his notes to you and read aloud which the notes can be found on his website after the lesson but without examples he mentions during the lecture.    frankly speaking, you can just skip all the lecture if you don't understand, because most people neither. Don't waste your time, try study by your own or go to math center. definitely usefuler than sitting in the lecture hall coping notes .however, if you want to pass you must !!!!!!!!! go to the tutorial ,it's more practical and  tutors may also give you some very very useful tips for the exam . Strongly recommend you tofinish all the question they gave you to practise. at least you will know what midterm and final look like.
reviews.comment_grading:
only homework midterm and final will be counted
the mean of the course are very low mostly below 50% so is sd because most people in 1012 aren't good at math so it's not hard to get b range if you score above mean (heard from the others, i don't have Brange......................)
reviews.comment_workload: there aren't any assignment or quiz but every week you have to finish an online homework through the website webwork. about 10-12 question each week. it's not very hard you should be able to handle if you attend the tutorial, you have unlimited chance to submit your answers untill correct. if you just don't give a shit you can just copy others.   (that's what most people do but I don't have friends...........)

reviews.author: Andyks
reviews.comment_content:
Just some introduction to calculus. Easy to handle if you are willing to spend time after lessons.

Week 1 Review of the concepts of functions and graphs.  
Week 2 Elementary functions.  
Week 3 Tangent and velocity; the limit of a function and limit laws.
Week 4 Continuity; limit at infinity; limit definition of derivative and rates of change.  
Week 5 Derivatives of basic functions; differentiation rules.
Week 6 Chain rule and implicit differentiation.
Week 7 Rates and related rates.  
Week 8 Mean Value Theorem. Maximum and minimum values.
Week 9 Derivatives and the shape of a graph; L'Hopital's Rule.  
Week 10 Curve sketching; optimization problems.  
Week 11 Antiderivatives; areas and distance travelled.  
Week 12 Definite integrals; Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.
Week 13 Net change; substitution rule.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Avery's lesson will make you sleep and you will copy a lot of concepts and definitions which are not too useful in your exams. There are little examples which will help you understand the concepts and applications but still not too useful.

Zeta's tutorial will focus on more useful applications of the theories in exams and there will be a thick practice. It is suggested to complete much of the practice if you have not learn calculus before or you are not so familiar with the concepts. It is really useful.

Because of the length of the course, Avery and Zeta will have to rush through the contents, there will be little time for you to do exercise. To catch up, you will have to spend much time doing Zeta's exercise at home.

It is suggested to take Zeta's notes even though you are not enrolled in Zeta's tutorial.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid term: 23/50 (mean 21.53/50)
Final: 70/100 (mean 44.69/100)
Webwork full mark
Overall get a B+ which is satisfying for the mark in mid term
reviews.comment_workload:
Remeber to study hard for mid term as the mean for mid term is usually low.
if you have not learnt calculus before and you want to get a good grade, please study hard. It takes a lot of time.
Zeta's tutorial session is useful, suggested to attend even if you are not enrolled in his session

reviews.author: dlwlrma
reviews.comment_content:
too difficult for the one who approach calculus for the first time
mainly focus on differentiation , integration , and the graphing
the time allocation is badly planned, the most difficult part use the least time to teach
reviews.comment_teaching: the teaching is extremely bad, just teach us theory and its proof, does not teach us how to apply the theory and how to use the theory practically
reviews.comment_grading: the grading is extremely bad, I know many people who got a D or even F in this course
reviews.comment_workload: with webwork every week, no quiz, a mid term exam ,and a final exam

reviews.author: Jimmy Mo
reviews.comment_content:
Straight forward. M2 things and new rules.
notes same for every year. Refer to sources if you want to study beforehand.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Detailed explanation. English good enough for a maths professor.
suggest ppl without M1/M2 background to attend tutorials or watch video for tutorials.

********there are no videos for lectures********only tutorials are taped.
reviews.comment_grading:
Had a bit of M2 background. (dropped after learning integration)
Did not do much exercise.
Started revising for mid term 3 days before, and final.4-5 days.

midterm above 1.3 SD
final (mean changes from year to year) : unknown mean and SD

My grade: A-
reviews.comment_workload: 10 webworks in total. Do pay attention to deadlines. Had missed one web work ******there was one webwork which its deadline was right after midterm.

reviews.author: eatingfreak
reviews.comment_content:
DSE M2 stuff
Avery does the proving and Zeta does Maths questions with you
reviews.comment_teaching:
Avery proved the equations or concepts, which turned out to be quite boring to students who do not have a great interest in mathematics so I skipped his lectures later on. And he spoke quite slow and in Hong Kong-ish English.
Zeta, on the other hand, taught really fast and precise, sometimes a bit too fast that it was not easy to follow. The good thing is that he uploaded his class videos a day or two after so you can watch it again to make yourself understand better. You can benefit quite a lot as long as you really finish exercises he assigned and try your best to follow.
reviews.comment_grading: The mean is quite low, I guess that's because many of us didn't have M2 in our high school but I still got a bad grade haha
reviews.comment_workload: webwork has to be done usually weekly or biweekly

reviews.author: Edenyt
reviews.title: ok
reviews.comment_content:
mostly like  M2 in DSE
content is 90% the same with math 1013
mainly learn the limit, differentiation, derivative
reviews.comment_teaching:
his teaching is very boring for me, mainly explain the math concept, very difficult to understand, almost skip all the lecture as his lecture is always at 9 am and will fall asleep easily
the tutorial is more helpful for me and i attend the most tutorial, will teach how to do exercise
reviews.comment_grading:
have the midterm, final and webwork
mean is about C
need work super hard to have a good grade unless u have dropped M2 before
reviews.comment_workload: ok, with around 10webwork assignment for the whole term, don't have any extra assignment

reviews.author: asdfg
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1 - Functions and graphs, exponential functions, transformations of graphs
Week 2 - Logarithmic functions, trigonometric functions
Week 3 - Trigonometric identities, concept of a limit
Week 4 - One-sided limits, infinite limits and limits at infinity
Week 5 - Continuity, concept of a derivative
Week 6 - Differentiation rules
Week 7 - Chain rule, implicit differentiation
Week 8 - Higher derivatives, rate and related rates
Week 9 - Minimum and maximum
Week 10 - Optimization, L'Hopital Rule
Week 11 - Anti-derivatives, indefinite integrals
Week 12 - Definite integrals, Fundamental Theorem of Calculus (FTC)
Week 13 - Substitution method
reviews.comment_teaching: If you have any questions, you could feel free to ask the professor. He is really nice and able to explain it quite detailed. However, the TA does not have such patience. If you don't understand after her explanation, don't ask her again. Try to ask the professor.
reviews.comment_grading:
Even you have studied hard, you may not get a good grade. Most of the people could not answer the questions that the professor asked.

Someone with M2 bases will feel that it is quite easy for them and they may able to get a good grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
Only have about 3-4 online questions per week in canvas
Attendance will be taken once a week.

reviews.author: çš®æ–¯å¡
reviews.comment_content: a lot of topics are required to study
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching of avery is boring and theoretical. Since mid-September  , I skipped all the lecture by Avery and only attended the tutorial. Zeta's teaching is focus on examination skills so will be more useful of the people that are weak at Maths
reviews.comment_grading:
78.x% get A-
Most of the webwork answer can be got from the internet or online calculator. Finish all webwork can add few percent of final grade so it is recommended to do ( If  u dont know u can ask ur friends so no difficulty at all )
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is ok. Webwork is the only homework and u can choose not to do it. If u do more exercise in zeta's notes u will have better result in the examination.

reviews.author: dondondon
reviews.title: Worst course ever
reviews.comment_content: As its course name, mainly cover calculus stuffs like limits, derivatives and integration. As a course designed for students who have not studied calculus during secondary education, it is really hard to catch up with the content.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very, very bad. Avery only focus on concepts but dont really teach how to solve the questions. Kitty, the TA,  also teaches poorly. In her tutorials, she often calculate the questions wrongly herself and only usually only about 10 students attend her tutorials. On the other hand, Zeta, who will teach one lecture session, do demonstrate how to solve different kinds of problems and in a relatively good way. He also prepared a set of exercises for us and if you do all questions in it, it should be able to help you understand more.
reviews.comment_grading:
A few sets of webwork, one mid-term and final exam.

No attendance will be taken in lectures and tutorials.

Bad. But it is probably because of how hard the content is for non-maths lovers. Mean for the final exam is just about 3x%.
reviews.comment_workload: Although compulsory workload for the courses is not much, approximately one webwork per 1-2 weeks consisting of at most 15 questions, you really need to spend a lot of time after lessons to practice doing the questions.

reviews.author: qwerty
reviews.title: Not bad
reviews.comment_content:
Pre calculus (identities, arcsin, arccos, arctan etc)
Binomial thm (optional but very useful in In)
Limit
Asymptotes, horizontal and vertical
Squeeze thm
Mean value thm
Differentiation
Chain rule
Optimization
Graphing
Extrema
Tangent lines
Summation
Integration
Substitution rule
Riemann sum (right left and mdpt)
Fundamental thm of calculus
reviews.comment_teaching:
Kitty is an inadequate tutorial instructor. All she does is mutter and write out the answers for the exercises without explaining adequately. Her tutorial is useless. And when u ask her questions, she justs give short, abrupt  answers with no elaboration. Simply put, she's a good mathematician, but by no means an adequate instructor
Many ppl dont like the instructor, Avery but he's actually very good. His explanations can be long winded but the details in his steps are very important. If u understand those details, the webwork will be very easy. Helpful instructor, will answer any questions u may hv. His exam questions are quite tricky. Some are taken out of webwork.
IA Zeta Chan(not found in instructor column) is the best. Explains very clearly. Best presentation and the most prepared. Also since his sessions are recorded, it is easy to catch up. His lectures revise Avery's main pts so all the essentials are there.
reviews.comment_grading: If u complete all the webwork and get 1sd above mean for final and midterm, u can get into a range.
reviews.comment_workload:
Webwork x10 (must hand in, grade saver)
Midterm x1 (8ish mcq, 7ish written, not too bad this one)
Final x1 (tricky)
Zeta's lecture notes (need not hand in, but very useful if u wanna take a practice run.)

reviews.author: mcli
reviews.comment_content: M2 stuff including functions,limits,differentiation and integration but some of them are Pure Math like L'Hopital's Rule
reviews.comment_teaching:
His accent may not be acceptable for someone as he has heavy Cantonese accent.
Most of the example and proof he teaches can be found on his website,but some of the examples may be presented in a different way.
He teach with heart in fact but there are not many people like having his lesson
reviews.comment_grading:
better compared to Math 1013
I get 0.5sd above mean in midterm
1 sd above mean in final
homework full marks
got B+
It is important to get full marks in homework,you can try the questions for infinite times and some of the question can be found in google
However,this course is still not very good grade since several marks below mean in the final may give you a C+ even you get above mean in the midterm.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite heavy for students haven't study M2 before,it is a 4 credit course
Notes with 11x pages will be given by Zeta,you can do all of them but it will requires a lot of time
Luckily, efforts can ensure you a good grade in this course.

reviews.author: michelle hola
reviews.title: The most challenging course for fm
reviews.comment_content:
Most of them are about M2 stuff( Limit, Differentiation, Integration) with some new contents( Sandwich Theorem, Lhopital Rule).

For the details, please refer to other's reviews.
reviews.comment_teaching:
In the lecture session, Avery mainly focuses on the proving of different equations. Although they are completely trashy that could never be used in the exam, you might somehow find them interesting. Just like you know 1+1=2 , but you have never been told what caused it to be neither in primary school nor secondary school. If you want to explore the secrets of Mathematics as a Math fanactic. Go for it.

If you just want to have a good grade, you MUST go to the tutorial session, be it Kitty's or Zeta's. In Kitty's tutotial, the good thing is that her notes are very comprehensive and neat with the working steps clearly shown, despite her weakness in explaning stuff( or my weakness in understanding lol). In Zeta's tutorial, he will show many examples of different types of questions. If you are stuck at some junctures and ask him, he can point it out quickly and clarify your mind. So, depends on which way of learning you prefer, choose the tutorial to go.
reviews.comment_grading:
Webwork 15%
Midterm 30%
Final 55%

Midterm: mean 20/50 sd 11
Final mean 43/100 sd 20
I have gotten ~73% overall and turns out to be B+
( Zero M1/M2 foundation in advance)
reviews.comment_workload:
Webworks are introduced about twice a month. If you are not capable of doing so, you can either go to MSC or go to Yahoo Answer.

If you are a math idiot like me, to get a better grade, finish as much exercise as you can. Only through practising will help you to explore more variety types of questions that similar questions might be asked again in the exam. At least it happened this time.

Not recommending to buy a book that is recoommended by the course, get a M2 book from your friend is better.

reviews.author: ustiong
reviews.comment_content: Same as other reviews, not too many changes, also teach from the basic limits concept, differentiation, integration and their applications.
reviews.comment_teaching:
For the main lecture, Avery taught the concepts and proofs with his hand written notes. Same contents would be written down together with students in different lecture section. But after finishing 1 topic, there was a pdf ver. notes uploaded on Avery's own website. That notes should be a part of the reference book, and almost same as Avery hand written one.

For another lecture and tutorial session, Zeta and Kitty will do their demonstrations respectively. Exercises were provided by Zeta and needed to collect from the Math Support Center. Although it was thick, it won't be too challenging for the students who had studies M1/2 during secondary school.

For the WebWork, it provided unlimited attemps so it also not a big problem. Web search is ok when doing the exercise and easy to calculate them out
reviews.comment_grading:
Overall C+.
((Haven't study M1/2 in my secondary life; All webwork exercises were finished as well
reviews.comment_workload: Some questions in Final exam were looked similar to the exercises. If you have finished all those questions, exam will be fine.

reviews.author: honestreview
reviews.title: easy, uninformative, and a bit disappointing
reviews.comment_content: As the most basic and important course for a university student, this course failed to equipped students with enough knowledge about Calculus. Compared to nearby Asian universities and Ivy League universities, this course is amazingly uninformative. To be honest, the 2 week pre-Calculus course I took in the summer at my home country covers more subjects and depth of Calculus than this course. Even Math 1013 is not enough(I took a look at their final exam papers)
reviews.comment_teaching: the professor is very nice. But someone may complained about his accent and he liked to say "ummmm" from time to time.
reviews.comment_grading: Very good. Since the mean is only about half of the full mark.
reviews.comment_workload: one Webwork assignment per week. Considering the difficulty and number of problems, you only need to spend about 1-2 hours on each.

reviews.author: Luic C
reviews.comment_content:
It is M2 stuff more than M1  from what I have heard (but I didn't study M1M2 before so I can't tell the difference). But the main flow goes from precalculus->limit & continuity-> differentiation and application -> integration

Week 1 Review of the concepts of functions and graphs.  (1.2-1.3; Appendix A.)
Week 2 Elementary functions.  (1.5-1.6; Appendix B-D.)
Week 3 Tangent and velocity; the limit of  a function and limit laws.  (2.1-2.3.)
Week 4 Continuity; limit at infinity; limit definition of derivative and rates of change.  (2.5-2.7.)
Week 5 Derivatives of basic functions; differentiation rules.  (2.8, 3.1-3.3.)
Week 6 Chain rule and implicit differentiation.  (2.8, 3.1-3.3.)
Week 7 Rates and related rates.  (3.7-3.9.)
Week 8 Maximum and minimum values.  (3.10, 4.1.)
Week 9 Derivatives and the shape of a graph; L'Hopital's Rule.  (4.3-4.4.)
Week 10 Curve sketching; optimization problems.  (4.5-4.7.)
Week 11 Antiderivatives; areas and distance travelled.  (4.9, 5.1.)
Week 12 Definite integrals; Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.  (5.2-5.3.)
Week 13 Net change; substitution rule.  (5.4-5.5.)
reviews.comment_teaching:
I did go to his lessons even though they are all morning 9am sections. But then after seeing the midterm exam results I realized that it is all useless. So I ditched all his lessons.
For the tutorial, the tutor doesn't seem to know what she is doing and how to tutor. So study by yourself is actually more effective than listening to their teaching.
reviews.comment_grading:
For my midterm got just above mean and final above mean and I got B range.
Based on other's comments, having midterm above mean, if your final is:
above 7X%, it gives you a B range.
above 81%, it gives you a A- at least.
reviews.comment_workload:
It depends on your natural ability in the end. If you are a slow learner, than you need to pay more effort by doing all of Zeta's practices.
But the thing is there is still the last piece of webwork due before the day of the final and I almost missed that. So make sure you check very frequently for webworks until the last minute of final.

reviews.author: yh.hohoho
reviews.title: just.calculus
reviews.comment_content:
- calculus from zero

Week 1 Review of the concepts of functions and graphs.
Week 2 Elementary functions.
Week 3 Tangent and velocity; the limit of a function and limit laws.
Week 4 Continuity; limit at infinity; limit definition of derivative and rates of change.
Week 5 Derivatives of basic functions; differentiation rules.
Week 6 Chain rule and implicit differentiation.
Week 7 Rates and related rates.
Week 8 Maximum and minimum values.
Week 9 Derivatives and the shape of a graph; L'Hopital's Rule.
Week 10 Curve sketching; optimization problems.
Week 11 Antiderivatives; areas and distance travelled.
Week 12 Definite integrals; Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.
Week 13 Net change; substitution rule.
reviews.comment_teaching:
4 credits course:
. 2 lectures per week by avery
. 1 lecture per week by zeta
. 1 tutorial per week by kitty

. avery does the proof, but... boring (?)
. zeta teaches his own things, exams oriented
. kitty seems to be nice, might be good to ask her in cantonese after class... no comment
reviews.comment_grading:
students enrolled have varied math skills.
mean for midterm and final < 50%, although questions are really not hard if you have some sense of math

good grade overall, at least better than its counterparts, and no need to work too hard if you are not pursuing an A+ which is reachable
- getting sth around 80 can still put you into A range.
reviews.comment_workload:
i skipped most of the classes, so no workload besides webwork once a week
9 webwork: really light for a 4 credits course

. symbolab
. khan academy
will be good friends of yours!

reviews.author: ptrknow
reviews.comment_content:
Please refer to other comments.

Note that the pace of teaching is fast. Spending effort to keep up with the pace is quite a must.
reviews.comment_teaching:
CHENG, Kam Heng:
Yes. I attend MATH1013's lecture instead of 1012's. Avery is quite infamous afterall.

Henry prepares very detailed notes and additional practices (which are very difficult), but you may need to individually ask him in order to gain the access on canvas.

He will write out all the stuff (proofs and solutions) on the whiteboard. Making sure you are with him when he is writing.

There is a break within every lecture. Feel free to ask him questions when in doubt. His explanation is generally detailed and understandable.
Right before midterm and final, he will teach us to do some past paper questions. 1013's questions are really challenging when compared to 1012's.

Zeta Chan:
Exam-oriented style. You should take a copy of his note and do practices on the questions of the note. This is particularly important for those who didn't study M2 before.

His explanation to solving questions is clear. Attending his tutorial is really quite optional because there are recorded videos uploaded on canvas afterwards. Of course, you might need to ask him questions and you better attend the tutorial if so (there will be more guys waiting for him in MSC).
reviews.comment_grading:
Maybe.. fair? I guess.

Midterm
Overall mean: 20/50 (40%)   Overall SD: 10.1 (20.2%)

Final
Mean of my class: 47/100   SD of my class: not announced yet

My mark for reference:
Webwork (15%): 100/100
Midterm (30%): 30/50
Final (55%): 91/100
Overall: 83/100
Grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
This might be an easy course for those who had dropped M2, but this is absolutely not the case for those who didn't take M2 at all (except that you are a genius).

If you had no M2 background before (like me), constant effort is mandatory and required in order to secure a better grade.

This is gonna be tough. Good luck.

reviews.author: anony262
reviews.title: Lube up
reviews.comment_content:
Content is pretty okay if I'm being honest. I did IB Math Studies (lol) and I was able to eventually understand and comprehend everything, so don't be too worried if you're bad at math. The main focus of this course is limits, derivatives, and integration. Everything else is minor and is just based off those main three.

Make sure you understand related rates and optimization. They love to test on those!
reviews.comment_teaching:
Just. No. You can get much better teaching from the following links:

Organic Chem (Math) Tutor https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rCxi-O79sVo&list=PL0o_zxa4K1BVKErFko9je9IBZ0hXWXVtV

and KhanAcademy
reviews.comment_grading:
Webwork - Straightforward. If you're struggling you can go to the math support center OR copy and paste the question into Google. 9/10 there will be a solution on Yahoo answers.

Midterm - Holy hell. Literally the WORST paper I have ever laid eyes on in my life. You know it's bad when the guy next to you opens the paper and says "f*ck". The mean was 19.9/50. Let that sink in. Not even 50%. Worst paper ever. Thankfully, Avery noticed that maybe he made it slightly too challenging...

Final - So so so so so much better. Avery heard our pleas and made this paper so much easier. For once I didn't want to kill myself mid-exam. This is the only reason I'm giving grading a B.
reviews.comment_workload: So much workload if you're new to the calculus. I remember staying up late every night doing the practice problems from Zeta's tutorial class (which, by the way, are much easier than the exam questions). If you work hard enough and try to understand the techniques and reasoning behind the theories, you'll do great.   Highly recommend watching videos explaining the concepts.

reviews.author: nora
reviews.comment_content: Lecture not very useful but tutor is very good. Especially Zeta. Although he sometimes will have a bad mood. Mainly limit, differentiation and integration.
reviews.comment_teaching: He will keep on write different notes in the lecture and try to teach you how to do the question by theory. Mainly theory and he will seldom teach how to do a question. Therefore, I don't really think his teaching is good.
reviews.comment_grading: Mid term and final are hard. Therefore you must complete webwork!! It is because webwork counts for 15% of the mark!
reviews.comment_workload:
For the whole semester, need to do a total of 9 webwork.
Each webwork will have more than a week for you to complete. So the workload is still ok if you can manage your time well.

reviews.author: Rainbowmakssci
reviews.title: Good professor Average grade
reviews.comment_content: All M2 stuff, DSE level. But it is so tedious if you have no fundamental math background as it is a 4 credit bearing course.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teacher emphasises on self learning process such as flipped class. He is lenient to students and I think he is capable to teach.
reviews.comment_grading:
Average

Mid term mean 17, highest 44 I got 21, just above mean. I predict I can have a B- if I continue to be above mean
reviews.comment_workload: Very light, only 3 canvas questions per 2 weeks (around) Go to lessons on time for attendance marks

reviews.author: Leon H
reviews.comment_content:
Basic concepts of calculus including differentiation and integration.

1. Pre-calculus
2. Limits
3. Differentiation
4. Intergration
reviews.comment_teaching: Since I have never attend any of the classes, nothing much I can say about the teaching.
reviews.comment_grading:
If you have learn calculus before, it won't be a problem to get an A range.

I never attended any of the lectures or tutorials and got more 48/50 in midterm and 90/100 in final. Got an A+ at the end.

Grading Scheme:
WebWork 15%
Midterm    30%
Final         55%
reviews.comment_workload:
Just remember to finish the webwork in time. It doesn't matter how many attempts you try. As long as you get the answer right in the end you'll get a full mark in the homework part.

Zero workload for those who have learned some basic calculus concepts before.

reviews.author: reosaki
reviews.comment_content:
The class just covers the basic curriculum in mainland's high school.

The homework is too boring.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Avery is a good teacher who always tries to explain the concepts as clearly as possible. He delivers a good presentation with logical thinking.

For me the only thing to criticise is that his teaches this class.
reviews.comment_grading: Though it's the beginning of the semester I firmly believe that I'll get an A.
reviews.comment_workload: It's pretty considerate that you don't need to attended the lecture or tutorial either.

reviews.author: kattsang
reviews.comment_content: The contest is similar to what you have learnt in M1 and M2 in dse level. People without any background in M1 and M2 may find it difficult.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is boring. In lecture, all he talks about is proof and teaches nothing about solving maths problems. Tutorials are more useful because the tutor gives you exercises to do.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grade ok
People who dropped M1 and M2 can easily get grade A.
reviews.comment_workload:

reviews.author: TH WONG
reviews.title: A nice course for students without calculus background
reviews.comment_content:
1) Pre-calculus (including types of various functions etc.)
2) Limit (limit, asymptotes etc.)
3) Differentiation (differentiation techniques, Lâ€™Hospitalâ€™s Rule, curve sketching etc.)
4) Integration (indefinite integral, summation, fundamental theorem of calculus)

The course introduces the basics of calculus to students without DSE M1/M2. I think this course is indeed very suitable for beginners. And thanks to this course, I could then handle MATH 1014 in spring.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr. Ching is quite good at explaining the basic ideas in calculus. As a beginner, I think his lectures are effective to introduce me the new concepts.

TA Zeta is very helpful and his tutorial notes are good.
reviews.comment_grading:
Webwork 15%
Midterm exam 35%
Final exam 50%

As this course is the basic course, the calculations in the exams aren't very difficult, and the questions are quite straight forward.

Webwork: 100/100
Midterm: 45/50 (mean around 28, sd around 14)
Final: 95/100 (mean & sd forgot)
Overall 94%, A+

The grading is reasonable and quite good.
reviews.comment_workload: The only homework is the webwork, so the workload is quite light. But the time for revision varies from student to student and it depends a lot on where you are aiming. Spending more effort is recommended if you aim high. The exercises in the text book and the tutorial notes are useful.

reviews.author: tschanag
reviews.comment_content:
Basic calculus
Includes limit, differential calculus, integral calculus.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Avery's teaching makes the course hard to follow.

TA Kitty Lee's tutorials were far from satisfactory. Not only her tone was larthargic, but also with an extremely slow teaching speed.

TA Zeta Chan Yun Hung was very helpful. He explained the steps,tho not quite thoroughly, and provided enough practice questions for us. You can find him at MSC.

My course is 9am class and I often skipped lectures of Avery. I stopped going to the tutorial since I found that useless.

I think Youtube and khan academy helped me a lot in understanding the course. So even if you skip lectures, it will be totally fine.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework 100%
Midterm 78%
Final 83%
Overall 84% Graded A
reviews.comment_workload:
Webwork was easy and had only 9 throughout the whole sem.

Tutorial notes from Zeta had many questions, but it is optional. Finishing them all will make this course a heavy workload. So I tried to finish it by skipping some easy questions.

Overall, this course is quite easy.

reviews.author: boboooooo
reviews.comment_content: This is an introductory course in one-variable calculus, the first in the Calculus I and II sequence, designed for students that have not taken HKDSE Mathematics Extended Module M1 or M2. Topics include functions and their limits, continuity, derivatives and rules of differentiation, applications of derivatives, and basic integral calculus.
reviews.comment_teaching: Zeta is the best. Remember to go math support center that can help u a lot.
reviews.comment_grading: if you pay effort on it, u can get a high marks
reviews.comment_workload: Dont have a heavy workload, Only have webwork , mid term and final exam.

reviews.comment_content: Took the course during a regular semester, as one  of my pre reg. Had no previous exposure to calculus. Learning all those concept with so little time is  definitely torture.

Not. Helping. At. ALL.
Attending lectures and tutorial won't do any good. Rotting in library might make a bigger difference than the lecture
reviews.comment_grading: Passed with loads of effort.Mid term and final are way too difficult than things that were taught in lectures and tutorials. Bad grade.
reviews.comment_workload: One online exercise every week, not difficult cause you can keep trying until you get the right  answer so it's alright.

reviews.author: NTS
reviews.title: MATH 1012
reviews.comment_content:
Basically DSE M2 Content, but for non-M1 and non-M2 takers

Official textbook for MATH 1012:
J. Stewart, Calculus Early Transcendentals, 7th edition, Brooks/Cole.
Â 
Tentative Teaching Schedule:
Week 1 - Functions and graphs, exponential functions, transformations of graphs
Week 2 - Logarithmic functions, trigonometric functions
Week 3 - Trigonometric identities, concept of a limit
Week 4 - One-sided limits, infinite limits and limits at infinity
Week 5 - Continuity, concept of a derivative
Week 6 - Differentiation rules
Week 7 - Chain rule, implicit differentiation
Week 8 - Higher derivatives, rate and related rates
Week 9 - Mean Value Theorem (MVT), minimum and maximum
Week 10 - Optimization, L'Hopital Rule
Week 11 - Anti-derivatives, indefinite integrals
Week 12 - Definite integrals, Fundamental Theorem of Calculus (FTC)
Week 13 - Substitution method

Actually not different from MATH 1013, just to separate students into 2 groups
reviews.comment_teaching:

For the content taught, some methods and ways he explained will simply make you further confused..

Midterm

But for L3, canvas is used and there is a limit on the attempts on questions.. a little unfair and demanding..

reviews.author: ig
reviews.comment_content:
This course covers:
1. Limit
2. Differentiation
3. Integration

An introduction to calculus. The content is almost the same with calculus 1B, but a simplified version.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Avery Ching's lecture is quite clear, but boring. You can skip the lectures and it won't be a problem. Mostly he prove formulas during his lectures. There are 3 lectures per week, and Avery teaches 2 of them. The third lecture is taught by the TA, Chan Yun-Hyung. It is better, plus he gives out lecture notes on his lecture.

The tutorials are more helpful than lectures, as the TA discuss problems, not just concepts like in lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is better than math1013's grading. The mean for mid and final is around 50-60. Getting an A is definitely possible. Just do the problems in the lecture notes given by the TA, study the past papers, and you will be fine.

Grading scheme:
15% webwork
35% mid
50% final
reviews.comment_workload: Webwork almost every week, not bad as you can try to solve the problems as much as you can without any deduction. Getting 100% in webwork is really easy, as there is no limit on the number of tries. The webwork is almost the same with math1013. I think there is a total of 9 webworks with around 10 questions each.

reviews.author: syunaa
reviews.comment_content:
basic calculus knowledge including pre-calculus, limit, derivative, antiderivative andintegral
It may be hard to catch up for calculus begininners as the course covers too many things within short period.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professer seems to avoid eye contact but explains given examples very kindly. Also his lecture notes are clear. However, as we have limited during lectures, you'd better attend tutorials for better understanding and more practice.
reviews.comment_grading:
Not really bad.
I got A- while my final grade was 81.XX.
reviews.comment_workload:
Light workload compared to the other math1012 classes
We do not have webwork but have to do some online exercises.

reviews.author: dansonmak
reviews.title: EASY TO HANDLE
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1 Review of the concepts of functions and graphs.  
Week 2 Elementary functions.  
Week 3 Tangent and velocity; the limit of  a function and limit laws.
Week 4 Continuity; limit at infinity; limit definition of derivative and rates of change.  
Week 5 Derivatives of basic functions; differentiation rules.
Week 6 Chain rule and implicit differentiation.
Week 7 Rates and related rates.  
Week 8 Mean Value Theorem. Maximum and minimum values.
Week 9 Derivatives and the shape of a graph; L'Hopital's Rule.  
Week 10 Curve sketching; optimization problems.  
Week 11 Antiderivatives; areas and distance travelled.  
Week 12 Definite integrals; Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.
Week 13 Net change; substitution rule.

The examples given in the lecture are important for the mid term and final.
In fact, you can skip most of exercise if you understand those examples.

35% mid-term
15% webworks
50% final
overall ~81 and i got an A in this course

integration and differentiation

reviews.author: BPiggy
reviews.comment_content: The content is very difficult to understand by the person without any previous knowing about calculus. The content is too much for a course within one semester which let students to have a hard time following up.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor has a very large accent which makes the english hard to understand. The teaching was about to prove the calculus rules but not how to use them. Going to lectures seemed not useful in passing in midterms and finals.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading was higher than average as the overall score with a mean resulted in a C+.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is high, the webwork assignments were difficult and was many and it seemed overwhelming.

reviews.author: C.ko
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1 Review of the concepts of functions and graphs
Week 2  functions.  
Week 3 Tangent and velocity; the limit of  a function and laws
Week 4 Continuity; limit at infinity; limit definition of derivative and rates of change
Week 5 differentiation rules
Week 6 Chain rule and implicit differentiation
Week 7 Rates and related rates
Week 8 Mean Value Theorem. Maximum and minimum values
Week 9 Derivatives and the shape of a graph; L'Hopital's Rule.
Week 10 Curve sketching,  optimization problems
Week 11 Antiderivatives,  areas and distance travelled
Week 12 Definite integrals; Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
Week 13 substitution rule
reviews.comment_teaching: The prof doesn't explain the concepts clearly and most of the students can hardly understand the concepts behind. However, the tutorials are far more useful. It is worth to attend the tutorials so as to get a better understanding on the content.
reviews.comment_grading: Not very good.
reviews.comment_workload:
I think the workload isquite heavy.
There is webwork for every two weeks, which consists of a lot questions and it takes time to complete all of them, though there's unlimited attempts. Besides, there is also
one midterm exam and one final exam.

reviews.author: RyanTo
reviews.title: Horrible teaching and grading
reviews.comment_content: The content is too hard for beginners and the schedule is outrageously packed. The content is too hard for beginners and the schedule is outrageously packed. The content is too hard for beginners and the schedule is outrageously packed.
reviews.comment_teaching: The accent of the professor is so disturbing and it's too hard for students to understand everything he says.The accent of the professor is so disturbing and it's too hard for students to understand everything he says.
reviews.comment_grading: Most horrible. It's very harsh for beginners to get a low grade in maths.
reviews.comment_workload: The web work is extremely hard and of huge amount.

reviews.author: biochemnerd
reviews.title: Just get done with it tbh
reviews.comment_content:
Content is actually not that hard to grasp, the main focus is on differential calculus and limits. It starts basic with functions, (easier) limits then into derivatives, graphing and integration.
Topics are easy to follow as long as you practice the concept.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Avery's teaching is.... complicated. His accent is often hard to understand and distracting. He takes too many variables and notations to explain simple concepts, which can be confusing to many students (including me).
I would recommend going to tutorials and lecture by the TA instead, as they explain how to do questions and are generally helpful. Dave's (Au, Cheuk Yin) notes and explanations seemed good and he explained concepts well too.
reviews.comment_grading:
From what I've experienced this semester, it seems like it was absolute grading otherwise there is no other way to explain a B- hahaha (but im not sure on this)

Avery's course outline:
15% webwork
35% midterm exam
50% final exam
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is manageable, although WebWork is a royal pain to finish. WebWork is pretty much each week, and if you are not sure to solve them ask for help or google them haha.
TAs provide worksheets for practice and there's always the textbook if you're willing to do extra.

reviews.author: Bee Yip
reviews.comment_content: This course is difficult for most students who didn't study m2 in secondary school since most of the content is similar to MATH1013 added to some pre-calculus content such as radian, absolute value. The time given is obviously insufficient and we can hardly understand and handle those questions related to integration.
reviews.comment_teaching: Ku's teaching is good that he provided quite a lot examples for us and they included some special skills. Ku's notes are painstaking and clear.  Ching's teaching is bad that he just gave some useless definitions instead some simple and easy-understanding examples.
reviews.comment_grading: Although the content is difficult, but the overall grading is very nice as most the students taking this course haven't studied m2 before. ( I luckily got A- finally )
reviews.comment_workload: Yu provided some assignments with several questions through canvas after teaching each topic.

reviews.author: tcy_J
reviews.title: rubbish
reviews.comment_content:
this course suppose for the one who never study m2  but teaching nearly whole dse content in 3 month, how can we suppose to catch up?
it is hard for the one who have not study m2 before to catch up
reviews.comment_teaching: lectures are rubbish , no direct relation between the lecture and the exam . the tutorial is more useful since it teaches you how to do question and give time to you to practice.
reviews.comment_grading: over all 33% F
reviews.comment_workload: Webwork only but the webworks are difficult, it costs a lot of time . Exams are difficult too.

reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is quite clear, he will ask us if we can follow or have any problem. He will explain each steps clearly and give us example then exercise in each topic during lessons to help us have a better understanding, even better than going to tutorial. I even don't need to go to the tutorial section
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm quite easy, if do enough practise, can get high mark.
Final have some difficult questions, but have enough time to deal with it.
As the course do not have NDS(i think), the mean will not be too high.
If do enough practise can get good grade

Midterm:Full 50, mean28.4 High: 50 My score:46
Final:Full 100, mean 47.3 High:97  My score:88
Grading A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Not really heavy workload, no webwork but some Exercise on canvas instead, usually 3-4 question about each topic. Exercise is not hard to let us practise the basic concept.
In other words, the practise is not enough, so have to do more other exercise  to get more fundamental practise.
I just borrow the Dse M2 textbk from my friend and do the  exercise inside.

reviews.author: wongsenoch
reviews.title: Do not skip lessons
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1 Review of the concepts of functions and graphs.  (1.2-1.3; Appendix A.)
Week 2 Elementary functions.  (1.5-1.6; Appendix B-D.)
Week 3 Tangent and velocity; the limit of  a function and limit laws.  (2.1-2.3.)
Week 4 Continuity; limit at infinity; limit definition of derivative and rates of change.  (2.5-2.7.)
Week 5 Derivatives of basic functions; differentiation rules.  (2.8, 3.1-3.3.)
Week 6 Chain rule and implicit differentiation.  (2.8, 3.1-3.3.)
Week 7 Rates and related rates.  (3.7-3.9.)
Week 8 Mean Value Theorem. Maximum and minimum values.  (3.10, 4.1.)
Week 9 Derivatives and the shape of a graph; L'Hopital's Rule.  (4.3-4.4.)
Week 10 Curve sketching; optimization problems.  (4.5-4.7.)
Week 11 Antiderivatives; areas and distance traveled.  (4.9, 5.1.)
Week 12 Definite integrals; Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.  (5.2-5.3.)
Week 13 Net change; substitution rule.  (5.4-5.5.)

The content is adequate to explain fundamentals of calculus, but for better coverage, I recommend to learn the content from MIT OCW.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Avery has a strong Hong Kong accent, it may be quite intimidating for students as he said many 'ah, er, la'
He mainly focuses on proofs and steps of the examples, however, the examples he lists were too basic compared to the exam ones.
TA (Zeta) was impeccable in his teaching, his examples were relevant to the exams and were well-explained
reviews.comment_grading:
WeBWorK Online Homework: 15%
Midterm Exam: 35%
Final Exam: 50%

Webwork's help could be sought from MSC, pretty guaranteed a 15 % from the grade.
Final was much harder than mid-terms and have a lower mean, ~40%, while mid-terms have a mean ~50%.
reviews.comment_workload:
The content would get harder over the course, hence constant effort are needed.
Lectures did not require attendance, but I recommend to go to the lectures if the understanding of concepts were not clear.

reviews.author: Sunny Ng
reviews.title: A good start to calculus.
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1 - Functions and graphs, exponential functions, transformations of graphs
Week 2 - Logarithmic functions, trigonometric functions
Week 3 - Trigonometric identities, concept of a limit
Week 4 - One-sided limits, infinite limits and limits at infinity
Week 5 - Continuity, concept of a derivative
Week 6 - Differentiation rules
Week 7 - Chain rule, implicit differentiation
Week 8 - Higher derivatives, rate and related rates
Week 9 - Mean Value Theorem (MVT), minimum and maximum
Week 10 - Optimization, L'Hopital Rule
Week 11 - Anti-derivatives, indefinite integrals
Week 12 - Definite integrals, Fundamental Theorem of Calculus (FTC)
Week 13 - Substitution method

The course starts from the very beginning, where you learn about functions and limits before stepping into the world of calculus. As seen from the schedule above, the course content is not extremely tough, but students with no calculus background might find the exams a little bit challenging.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Albert is a decent lecturer. He is capable of delivering the course contents in an effective way. He places a lot of effort in making powerpoints, online self-learning materials as well as assignments and quizzes. He is very willing to answer students' questions and explains mathematical problems with examples in a good and logical way. If you attend all the lessons, understand the examples and work on the practices, you will do fine.

The TA, Kitty, is fair. She prepares a lot of exercises for practicing the learned topics. However, her delivery in English is average. She sometimes looks shy and speaks really softly.
reviews.comment_grading:
35% mid-term exam
50% final exam (includes everything)

Not much explanation needed here. The exams are pretty tough so it is important to make sure that you understand the concepts and practice regularly. If you do so, it is not surprising to end up with the A range.

10% online exercises

There are weekly online exercises, which in most cases, only consist of less than 5 questions. They are based on the online self-learning materials and are not too hard.  You can surely complete them within an hour.

5% class participation

Every week, there will be an in-class quiz and a group task. They are not long and they take up around an hour together. Both test our knowledge on the online self-learning materials posted on canvas. If you get a decent score, bonus points will be awarded, which counts for class participation.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload really depends on how hard you push yourself.

Apart from the weekly online exercises, there are no other homework or assignments. You only need to spend an hour outside lesson time.

However, it is highly recommended that you do regular exercises on taught topics and understand everything or else you will struggle before and during the exam.

reviews.author: tsepikling
reviews.title: Actually simple enough for beginners
reviews.comment_content:
I never study calculus before(in HKDSE). However, I found the difficulty of the course is reasonable and the instructor could explain those concepts with graphs or detailed procedures. Quite a lot of topics but the questions were not at an advanced level so beginners also can catch up easily.

I don't like Piazza. It is too difficult to use, especially for a mobile phone user.
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructor is nice and responsible, he can explain the concepts clearly with his powerpoint but a bit of boring as he always waits for student's responses. All in all, he did a good job. However, the tutor( Kitty) could not explain the question very clearly and personally I think the tutorial is useless, I only attended for 3(?) lessons.
reviews.comment_grading:
I got A+. Midterm:49/50. Final:90/100. Overall: about 92%.
I never study M1/M2 so the course is not that difficult.
reviews.comment_workload: Not very large. But I had one online quiz/assignment on Canvas every week, once I was late, the mark was deducted by 50%. So u must keep on doing the assignment and check the deadline.

reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching was not as good as I expected. His English accent was not good so I had a hard time to understand in the beginning. However, he uploads his lecture notes every time after the lecture to his course website, and that is really useful.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assessment

WeBWorK Online Homework: 15%
Midterm Exam (on 23rd Oct): 35%
Final Exam: 50%

Grading is actually pretty good.
Midterm: 30.26 (average), 12.58 (SD) out of 50
Final: 48.44 (average), 23.75 (SD) out of 100
I got 1SD above in both of my exams and got an A
reviews.comment_workload: Almost Weekly workload. It is doable but it requires some time.

reviews.author: matthewzayco
reviews.comment_content: The content is quite difficult, but its just basic calculus stuff. The main focus is on Limits, Differentiation and Integration, the stuff he did before barely came up on the test and is mostly basic graph and trig knowledge.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Avery likes to jump around and sometimes does not explain his steps very well. He does give a lot of examples though.

He also teaches us proof which we will never use unless you are doing maths as a major.
reviews.comment_grading:
To get a good grade is achievable, just make sure you do well in the first midterm exam. Some of the webwork is quite difficult but make sure you finish that. I got 92% for midterm and 60% for finals, finishing on a total of 78%, and I got an A-.

35% - Midterm
15% - Webwork
50% - Final
reviews.comment_workload: Lots of work if you wanna do good, do the questions that Zeta gives you, its similar to the exam format.

reviews.author: Sakamoto
reviews.title: Well, quite easy.
reviews.comment_content: Compared with 1013, the theorems are mostly covered but the proof is always skipped or just tricky ones. I was enrolled in this class by mistake(kind of) and I have some calculus background so I think it's too easy.
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructor is very responsible, and the TA in my tutorial is very enthusiastic. I think they are great.
reviews.comment_grading: Well, as I said in the "Content" column, I can't judge the grading because I've already learnt most of the knowledge. But one of my friends who enrolled in this class(with no doubt) got an A+. So I think the grading is quite good.
reviews.comment_workload: Well, the same webwork as 1013, so it might be a little bit hard for students enrolled in this class. The tests are just easy, so no much workload.

reviews.author: app_Sci
reviews.title: Suffering is a must if you are in SSCI or SENG that were forced to take this course without any M2 background.
reviews.comment_content:
The course teaches about 60% of M2 materials in 3 months for those who did not have M2 in HKDSE exam. Me myself found M2 textbooks very helpful in MATH 1012.
(Yes, M1 materials are less helpful than M2 materials.)
The teaching pace is indeed very fast, going through functions, limits, derivatives, application of derivatives and integrals in the 3 months.
quite chur for those who did not study any extended math in secondary school, like me.
reviews.comment_teaching:
He puts handwritten lecture notes in his course website.
If you are good in self-study, you do not have to go to his lectures and you can just read the lecture notes to learn.
His overall teaching is satisfactory.
I would recommend you to go to Zeta's lecture instead, his lecture is quite exercise- based.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is based on mean and SD.
The mean of exams would be around 55% and SD about 25% (Very big!)
I am above mean 0.5 SD and got a B+.
Because of big SD, even you are pretty far away from the mean, you cannot get very high marks.
In some posts, it was said that you could not get full credit if you do not answer using his method, but this is not true. In midterm, I answered a long question which involves limits. I made some very minor mistakes in my steps (like forgetting to put plus after the limit), got the correct answer anyway. I was granted full credit for that particular question afterall.
reviews.comment_workload: There is only webwork, and a midterm and a final. Although it sounds little, the questions in midterm and final often requires you to think more than what was mentioned in lecture notes and webwork, thus, you need to do lots of exercise outside class.

reviews.author: Kamal
reviews.comment_content:
Easy for those who took Extended Maths during DSE
Hard to catch up if you didn't study calculus before
5 topics in 3 months so the prof goes really fast to ensure that all the topics are covered in time for exam
reviews.comment_teaching: It is very hard to understand what the prof is saying 90% of the time, so it's better to skip lectures and study on your own. Attend tutorials as the TA will help with all the problems
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is tough as it is the easiest course on calculus thus many students will practice to perfect their grade.  So make sure you do all the webwork correct as it has unlimited tries and also study well for midterm. If you master the basics and practice regularly, then you should get a good grade
reviews.comment_workload:
Just one webwork each week roughly. Totally, webwork accounted for (10%)
Midterm (35%)
Final (50%)

reviews.author: Taker
reviews.title: good grade
reviews.comment_content:
Similar to secondary school's M1/M2 but included more content
Those who did not study M1/M2 before need more effort to catch up since the content of this course is similar to 1013 and one should not expect that this course is easier than 1013
reviews.comment_teaching: If you like maths, the teaching is good, since his teaching can improve your thinking in mathematics. Otherwise, if you only want to develop practical skills in doing maths, the lecture is boring to you, just go for the tutorial in this case. The TA's teaching is pretty good and his advice is precise and accurate.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is pretty fair I would say. Overall 83% having an A grade is surprising comparing to 1013 which adopts absolute grading (B+ in that case).
reviews.comment_workload:
I skipped almost all lectures and tutorial in this semester and still manage to take the exams. Just make sure you can do all the webworks by yourself and you should be fine.
However, it really depends whether you have studied M1/M2 or not. In my case I did so not much extra effort is needed.

reviews.author: erika.s
reviews.comment_content:
Intro to calculus. Topics include: Functions, Limits, Derivatives, Optimization, Integration.

Midterm mostly tested limits and final was predominantly on derivatives and integration. Make sure to know your graphs because both exams have long graph sketching questions.

Final is all inclusive, including midterm.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor is extremely bad at explaining, heavy accent, makes easy concepts very complicated.

It's better to skip lectures (No attendance, so its ok) and study lecture notes by yourself, with help from youtube videos e.g. Khan Academy to understand concepts rather than go to lectures and try to understand the professor.

TAs are more helpful, especially Dave. Be sure to go to tutorials.
reviews.comment_grading:
Harsh grading for an 'intro' to calculus, make sure you do well in midterm. Final is harder to score in so get a better mark in midterm. However overall, it's very hard to fail the course if you have done higher mathematics in high school and have a solid background in calculus.

Webwork: 15% of overall grade, can easily get full 15%
Midterm Mean: 28.5/50, 35% of overall grade
Final Mean: Unknown, 50% of overall grade

I scored below mean for both midterm and final, got C for 46% in the course overall. Hard to fail this course, so as long as you study well and are good at math, an A is definitely possible.
reviews.comment_workload:
High workload, webwork every week. Although webwork is not of high difficulty, and solutions for most questions can be found online if you absolutely have no idea how to solve them. Webwork has unlimited attempts, so very easy.

TA gives additional practice problems, if you choose to do these, then the workload is extremely high.

reviews.comment_content:
Week 1 Review of the concepts of functions and graphs.  (1.2-1.3; Appendix A.)
Week 2 Elementary functions.  (1.5-1.6; Appendix B-D.)
Week 3 Tangent and velocity; the limit of  a function and limit laws.  (2.1-2.3.)
Week 4 Continuity; limit at infinity; limit definition of derivative and rates of change.  (2.5-2.7.)
Week 5 Derivatives of basic functions; differentiation rules.  (2.8, 3.1-3.3.)
Week 6 Chain rule and implicit differentiation.  (2.8, 3.1-3.3.)
Week 7 Rates and related rates.  (3.7-3.9.)
Week 8 Mean Value Theorem. Maximum and minimum values.  (3.10, 4.1.)
Week 9 Derivatives and the shape of a graph; L'Hopital's Rule.  (4.3-4.4.)
Week 10 Curve sketching; optimization problems.  (4.5-4.7.)
Week 11 Antiderivatives; areas and distance travelled.  (4.9, 5.1.)
Week 12 Definite integrals; Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.  (5.2-5.3.)
Week 13 Net change; substitution rule.  (5.4-5.5.)

Avery's teaching makes the course hard to follow, it is quite difficult to follow what he is saying in lectures.

The TA (AU, Cheuk Yin), He is very, very useful in tutorials, and his way of teaching is very easy to understand.He has notes for the tutorials, and easy to understand.GOOD!!!!!!!

reviews.author: Jonas Lee
reviews.comment_content:
Basic calculus. The concept is entirely new for students without HKDSE M1/M2 experience.
Includes limit, differentiation, integration.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Avery's teaching makes the course hard to follow. I am not a math head and didn't know what he was teaching half of the lecture.

TA Zeta Chan was very helpful. He explained the steps and reasoning very well in tutorials and provided adequate exercise for us.

I gave up after 2 weeks and didn't attend the lectures very often. I went to all the tutorial and finished all the tutorial questions by myself.

I think watching khan academy is adequate for everyone to understand the course content. There is no need for attending the lecture.
reviews.comment_grading: Overall 70% Graded B
reviews.comment_workload:
Depends.
Webwork was quite easy and had only 9 throughout the whole sem.

Tutorial notes from Zeta had many questions, but it is optional. Finishing them all will make this course a heavy workload.

Overall, this is not a heavy workload course.

reviews.author: Kabul
reviews.title: Do past paper
reviews.comment_content:
This is my first as well as my last MATH course to be taken in UST. It's basically M2 stuff with a few additional theorems like the mean-value theorem and L'hÃ´pital rule. For those who have not taken M2 it could be a little bit hard to follow, so make sure don't skip any lectures, no matter how useless you think they are. Tutorials are good opportunities to have some practice and ask more "technical" questions, and before coming to the tutorials it's necessary to clarify the concepts in lectures first.

Topics include:
â™¦ Functions and their graphs;
â™¦ Trigonometric functions, exponential and log functions and their inverses;
â™¥ Limits, asymptotes of graphs, continuity;
â™¥ Derivatives of elementary functions, product and quotient rules, chain rule.
â™¥ Implicit differentiations.
â™¥ Rate of changes.
â™  Extrema of functions. The mean value theorem.
â™¥ Increasing and Decreasing functions. Curve sketching.
Optimizations.
â™  L'hÃ´pital rule.
â™  Riemann sums and definite integrals. The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.
â™¥ Integration by Substitution.

â™¦ DSE Maths Compulsory Parts
â™¥ DSE Maths Extended M2 Parts
â™  New Topics
reviews.comment_teaching:
CHING, Avery is a very clear-minded and logical professor, and he is able to present the basic concepts very well. However, he focuses mainly on the "philosophy" of maths rather than the "technical" aspects of how to solve mathematical problems. Sometimes he just confuses us even more as he gets more in depth in his own philosophy. If you can't catch up make sure you go to the Maths Support Center and don't be afraid to raise questions.

CHAN, Yun Hung (TA), on the other way round, focuses on solving problems more than introducing and explaining concepts. He has a very bad Hong Kong accent, and many international students complained that they didn't understand. However it should be understandable for the locals. As time is limited he often teaches VERY fast in the lectures. Make sure you really take out a piece of paper and a pen to have a try solving the problem, but not just sit there looking as he writes. Practice determines your grade.
reviews.comment_grading:
ğŸ’» 15%: WebWork
âœï¸ 35%: Midterms
âœï¸ 50%: Finals

Relative grading:
-1 SD: ~C-
Mean: ~C+
+1 SD: ~B+
> +1.1 SD: ~A range

However, it still depends on the professor, so...

Make sure you do all the WebWork and try to score full marks in every assignment. Full marks are expected for almost all students and if you fail to do so you will be at a huge disadvantage.

The midterm was quite easy, and shouldn't be a problem for those who had paid SOME effort in maths.
Mean: 26.68/50, SD: 13.45
My score: 50/50 (1.73 SD above mean)

The final was much harder and it tested on whether we had clear concepts and could present it in a logical manner. Any minor logical flaws can have your marks deducted, even if you have arrived at the right answer.
Mean: 48.64/100, SD: 22.61
My score: 99/100 (2.23 SD above mean)

Overall score: 99.5%
Final grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload in this course is the fortnightly WeBwork.
There are 9 of them, and they constitute 15% of your final grade. The WeBwork is quite challenging and asks tricky questions, so it costs a considerable amount of time to finish. Try to score full marks as it allows unlimited attempts.

reviews.author: CourseReviewer
reviews.comment_content:
Content is suitable for beginners in Calculus, although the pace is quite fast and there are a lot of topics to cover. Definitely should practice from the textbooks as they give you the correct mindset to solve problems.

Topics include:
Functions and their graphs;
Trigonometric functions, exponential and log functions and their inverses;
Limits, asymptotes of graphs, continuity;
Derivatives of elementary functions, product and quotient rules, chain rule.
Implicit differentiations.
Rate of changes.
Extremums of functions. The mean value theorem.
Increasing and Decreasing functions. Curve sketching.
Optimizations.
L'hÃ´pital rule.
Riemann sums and definite integrals. The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.
Integration by Substitution.

Don't freak out when the professor gives you extremely difficult past papers, I promise you that in reality, the midterms and the finals aren't that difficult!
reviews.comment_teaching:
Although the professor (CHING, Avery) is very smart, he is unable to teach well; it is quite difficult to follow what he is saying in lectures. He starts off with easy, understandable concepts, and the other minute he immediately starts solving a very difficult problem.

Similarly, the TA (CHAN, Yun Hung) often teaches in lectures as well. It's quite difficult to understand his accent, plus his teaching is worse than Avery's. Plus, although he can be approached in the MSC, he seems to "look down" on you.

The other TA (AU, Cheuk Yin), however, is the reason why the teaching of this course got a D and not an E. He is very, very useful in tutorials, and his way of teaching is very easy to understand. In addition, he is highly approachable and always seems to be ready to help you.
reviews.comment_grading:
If you have studied Calculus before, I don't think the grading is going to be a huge problem for you, because the midterm is relatively easy. Final was tough. The mean is also crazy high due to the fact that many people have studied Calculus.  (although, the content is really much! After all, it is a 4 credit course).

15%: WebWork
35%: Midterms
50%: Finals

Midterm: Mean: 30/50, SD: 12/50
Finals: Mean: 54/100, SD: 26/100

I got 36/50 and 62/100 with full WebWork
Received a B.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload in this course is only the bi-weekly Webwork that you need to do.

There are 10 of them, and one of them accounts for 1.5% of your final grade.

reviews.author: æå©·å©·
reviews.comment_content:
It's really easy and requires very little time to prepare for the tests.
In fact, you can get good grades simply by doing past papers and practicing some problems on the tutorial website( which is given by the teacher)
reviews.comment_teaching: no comment, I only attended one course xD
reviews.comment_grading:
No attendance
webwork (once a week) easy but need careful calculation, some problems and its solution can also be found not the internet (google)
one midterm and one final
reviews.comment_workload: only webwork , and it usually takes within or about an hour

reviews.author: jman123
reviews.comment_content: It's way too hard for students who never studied calculus.
reviews.comment_teaching: His accent was weird and it is hard to understand. He only tries to explain each theory in class once and skips all the steps. He leaves the calculation stuff to the TAs. The TAs are way better in teaching in how to calculate.
reviews.comment_grading: The paper is hard. The mean is still around 50% of the paper as some people had previous experience in calculus, and people who never studied it before will get really bad grades. Probably.
reviews.comment_workload: Webwork every week or so. So yeah.

reviews.author: scarlet
reviews.comment_content: The content is quite packed and there are quite a lot concepts to remember. It is really hard for those who had not taken M1/M2
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor's teaching is really bad, he just read from the powerpoint and did not thoroughly explain the underlying principles.He always come late and is not patient enough when asking him questions
reviews.comment_grading: very bad. I am a retake student and my final score is above nearly 1SD. My final grade comes out to be C+. And a friend of mine below 0.5 SD and he failed.The grading is bad and unfair,
reviews.comment_workload: Not much. Just some webwork online. You really need to practice a lot on the topics.

reviews.author: DoWtAr
reviews.comment_content:
Not really easy for those who didn't study M1/M2 in their secondary school.

You have to give a high effort to learn the content by yourself if you skip the lessons.
reviews.comment_teaching: Quite useful, he had prepared some notes and online learning materials for us.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grade is actually not that good, both my midterm and exam are above mean 0.5 sd and I finished all the webworks and turned out I earned a C+.

TBH, AVERY Ching is giving a better grade. Therefore, you better study it well in the fall semester.
reviews.comment_workload: Very light, there are only 1 mid-term , 1 final and 6/7 webworks.

reviews.author: RobYuen
reviews.title: F to B+, big thanks to the retake
reviews.comment_content: The content shifts to MATH1013, which is the same as 1012 with ~3 more theorems. Still tough when you failed the course last semester.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Intensive course based on practical problems. It should be a lot better than theory lectures if you do not understand theories, at least you can learn from exercises.

Prof. LAM and a lot of TAs are available to solve your questions with patience.

Overall good because mathematics needs intensive and repetitive training, and it is compulsory in this course.
reviews.comment_grading:
I got a B+, from an F in the fall semester

Classwork: 25%
You have to complete webwork assignments of around 30 questions twice a week, IN PERSON (essentially means attendance), however there are TAs available to ask.
Tutorial Quizzes: 20%
After the morning classwork, you get to a 3-5 question webwork quiz in the afternoon, this time there is no help from TAs.
Final Exam: 55%
Better than the fall semester one by Avery, easier, and most importantly you can have 1 piece of cheat sheet.
reviews.comment_workload: When you have to go to school twice a week, 10 to 4, during holidays, it is of course heavy. Though the grade is worth the work.

reviews.author: Gman
reviews.comment_content: The content is mainly Calculus  I. If you studied it before, you shouldn't really face too much of a problem.
reviews.comment_teaching:
It felt like at times attending the lectures didn't really help out all that much as it made things a little more confusing than it really needed to be.

The tutorial on the other hand was more informative and even though it was supposed to serve as recap of what we learnt, it was much easier understanding the concepts in the tutorials than in the lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
Even scoring the mean will only land you a C.
Their way of marking the midterm and exams is very specific:  if you do not follow/show some specific steps to obtain the final answer, you'll only get a third of the overall mark for the question even if the answer is correct.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is quite average and manageable. There is Webwork due each week along with a 'quiz'. However, these are not enough to get you a good grade in the mid-term and final and so needless to say, you need to practice a lot on own your own.

reviews.author: LamHo
reviews.title: For those suckers fail this course like me
reviews.comment_content:
Content is the same as Math 1013 boring as hell.
Homework: 25%
Tutorial Quizzes: 20%
Final Exam: 55%
reviews.comment_teaching: Whenever you are stuck with those hard ass questions, there are always TAs for you to ask. (Of course you can ask the professor yourself) I know I am never a smart kid and never will, but the TAs can still enable me to solve maths with detailed explanation.
reviews.comment_grading:
F to B-
Math noobs perfectly know how I feel
reviews.comment_workload: Go back to UST to have lessons for 3 days (damn right it takes your WHOLE DAY) in a week is not easy. Plus, there is one quiz after each lesson, 4 to 7 questions depending on different topics. No pay, no gain.

reviews.author: Pear
reviews.comment_content:
Just an introductory course of calculus
It covers most of differentiation but only till the beginning of integration
Integration of volume is out of syllabus.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Avery a very smart teacher
He can just write forever on the blackboard
He defines the definitions very clearly.
His accent is acceptable
However, it can be quite hard to keep up with his pace because there are many things that he expects you to understand when he skips some of the steps
So i would suggest going to tutorials and MSC. It helps a lot
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is pretty good in my opinion
my overall percentage was around 70% and i got A-
The exams and midterms are very hard, they are all very conceptual based.
You have to really understand the derivation of most theorems to be able to grasp a direction to solve Avery's questions
reviews.comment_workload: I would say that theres a lot of stuff to be learnt if you have never learnt any m2. You do have to put in a notible amount of effort to fully understand the concepts and apply them to the questions.

reviews.author: fanmatthew
reviews.comment_content: Although the course are created for students who didn't take or scored below level 3 in M2 in DSE, the content is exactly the same with 1013, student who skips all lesson might find hard to follow. But it doesn't take much time and effort to score above mean in mid-term and final.
reviews.comment_teaching: Pof. Ching's teaching is one of the best I have experienced in Science School. His pronunciation is loud and clear, the speed of speech is quite fast but still easy to follow. One thing to be noticed is that he speaks "Chin-glish", which is surprisingly fine for me as it's recognizable for local students like me.
reviews.comment_grading: I personally think this course's grading system is best for student like me, who is lazy and skips almost all lecture, and still hopes to score in B range.
reviews.comment_workload: This course has about 10 something webworks, and also a special lecture in the end of week which you have to finish a classwork before the end of it. There's no quizzes but only one mid-term and one final exam. The workload is overall good.

reviews.author: aishuj
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1 Review of the concepts of functions and graphs.  (1.2-1.3; Appendix A.)
Week 2 Elementary functions.  (1.5-1.6; Appendix B-D.)
Week 3 Tangent and velocity; the limit of  a function and limit laws.  (2.1-2.3.)
Week 4 Continuity; limit at infinity; limit definition of derivative and rates of change.  (2.5-2.7.)
Week 5 Derivatives of basic functions; differentiation rules.  (2.8, 3.1-3.3.)
Week 6 Chain rule and implicit differentiation.  (2.8, 3.1-3.3.)
Week 7 Rates and related rates.  (3.7-3.9.)

reviews.comment_teaching: You surely will not understand his accent. Which makes the lectures completely useless as I had a tough time just understanding what he was trying to say. E.g He will use phrases that make no sense. "your naive brains" "it is a mind-game". But he is dedicated to his work and puts in a lot of effort by writing out the notes all over the board. But you will spend time just copying down those notes and not understanding anything taught.
reviews.comment_grading: They are harsh. That's it. Even if your answer is right you can be marked down if they don't like the way you solved it.
reviews.comment_workload: It is a 4 credit course so it is really heavy on work. There are lectures, tutorials, and webwork. There is webwork almost every week, but completely useless because the exam is nothing like the questions from it.

reviews.author: Chad.H
reviews.title: Nice course for beginners
reviews.comment_content:
Almost same as math1013, but some theorem excluded
take quite a lot of time to talk about function (1/3 semester)
No quiz and homework, only midterm and final exam.
Webwork 12%
Midterm 33%
Final 55%
reviews.comment_teaching:
Avery is a really nice professor, notes provided on the course website.
Tutor's notes are really good, but still similar to Math 1013.
reviews.comment_grading:
Overall  get 82.95%, above 1.9 sd , A+
mean 50, sd 17
I get 90% in midterm, and 75% in final
I think is really fair, and not hard to get this mark
(P.S. I didn't take M1/2 before)

reviews.title: Same as Math1013
reviews.comment_content: Same as MATH1013 and M2 in DSE. Recommended to those who have dropped M2 in secondary school coz most of the content is just the same.
reviews.comment_teaching: Haven't gone to his lesson so no comment lol
reviews.comment_grading:
I think grading is okay la coz math1012 is to let those who havent taken m1/2 in dse so i think the grading would not be too bad. Otherwise, no difference between taking 1013 or 1012.
Final 60% Midterm 82%
A-
reviews.comment_workload:
Every math course just the same. Webwork around once a week.
Webwork same as math 1013.

reviews.author: Eugene
reviews.comment_content: Very basic. If you've studied calculus before, you should have no problem regarding the content of this course.
reviews.comment_teaching: At times, you may be better off not attending the lectures - the lecturer has a tendency of making simple calculations/steps incredibly confusing.
reviews.comment_grading: Scoring the mean will give you a C. Their way of marking exams (whether it be midterm or final) is very specific - if you do not follow specific steps to obtain the final answer, you'll get a third of the overall mark for the question despite getting the correct answer. In your answers, you'll also have to be clear and precise; otherwise, no marks will be given for your points unfortunately.
reviews.comment_workload: With webwork due every week, along with a "quiz", workload is adequate.

reviews.author: ykchan
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1 Review of the concepts of functions and graphs.  
Week 2 Elementary functions
Week 3 Tangent and velocity; the limit of  a function and limit laws
Week 4 Continuity; limit at infinity; limit definition of derivative and rates of change
Week 5 Derivatives of basic functions; differentiation rules.  
Week 6 Chain rule and implicit differentiation.
Week 7 Rates and related rates.
Week 8 Linear approximation and differentials; Maximum and minimum values.
Week 9 Derivatives and the shape of a graph; L'Hopital's Rule.  
Week 10 Curve sketching; optimization problems
Week 11 Antiderivatives; areas and distance travelled
Week 12 Definite integrals; Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.  
Week 13 Net change; substitution rule
